posts.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517741
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lime_mortar
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ek3aeUhHaFY
This guy made lime mortar by firing snail shells (calcium carbonate) in a kiln to decompose them into quicklime and then mixing them with water to form lime putty, and mixing in an aggregate like sand to make lime mortar. Limestone is a much better source of lime, but he didn't have access to it in his area.

I'm not sure if there were mortars made in ancient history which were more advanced than lime mortar, but this is what came to my mind.

Here are a few ideas for small, inexpensive tools that might make good stocking stuffers for someone who works in HVAC:

A small flashlight or headlamp: This can be useful for working in tight or dark spaces.

A set of hex keys or Allen wrenches: These are handy for tightening or adjusting screws with hexagonal heads.

A roll of electrical or duct tape: These can be useful for a variety of purposes, such as sealing air leaks or temporarily fixing loose wires.

A small set of screwdrivers: A set of flathead and Phillips head screwdrivers can be useful for many tasks, such as removing covers or tightening screws.

A multi-tool: A compact multi-tool with pliers, a knife, and other tools can be useful for many tasks, such as cutting wire or stripping insulation.

A wire stripper: This is a specialized tool for quickly and easily removing the insulation from electrical wires.

A digital thermometer: This can be useful for taking temperature readings in different parts of a heating or cooling system.

A set of small wrenches: A set of wrenches in different sizes can be useful for tightening or loosening bolts and nuts.

A set of cable ties: These can be useful for organizing and securing wires and cables.

A roll of Teflon tape: This can be used to seal threads on pipe fittings to prevent leaks.

Remember that these are just suggestions, and you should consider the specific interests and needs of the person you're buying for when selecting a stocking stuffer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517892
It sounds like your printer has sustained some damage to its external plastic shell. In general, it is best to use a plastic-specific adhesive for repairing plastic parts. This is because many adhesives, including super glue, are not specifically designed for use with plastic and may not provide a strong or long-lasting bond.

Instead, you may want to try using a plastic welding adhesive, which is specifically designed for bonding plastic parts together. These adhesives typically come in two parts that must be mixed together before use, and they often have a longer working time than super glue, which can give you more time to adjust the fit of the parts as you are bonding them together.

Additionally, you may want to consider using some plastic reinforcement, such as plastic welding rods, to help provide additional strength to the repair. This can help to ensure that the repaired area is strong enough to withstand normal use of the printer.

Overall, it is important to make sure that the repair is performed carefully and that the adhesive is allowed to cure fully before using the printer again. This will help to ensure that the repair is strong and will last for a long time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518728
>>2518726
What material are you using, and how are you engraving?

I have a CNC router and engrave wood from time to time.
The process is
>paint wood, wait till dry
>put blue painters tape on it (get the like 3" wide stuff)
>engrave THROUGH the blue tape

Now you can just paint into your engravings, wait for it to dry, remove tape and you have the contrasting colors.
You do have to have a tangible carved out line for the paint to go into.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518742
Well dont actually engrave it then, just paint it.
Create a stencil/mask with the laser

Throw the tape on, and then just barely hit it with enough power to cut out block letters.
Pull the letters off, and paint, just like a stencil.

You should be able to get it really crisp.
If not you really should just go buy a different router bit. You have to have a decent groove for paint to be visible, im not sure youll be able to do it cleanly or crisp with a laser

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521123
Terminating fibre is possible, but not easy, and not trivial to do self-taught.

Your two options are:
- 'traditional' polished and cemented ferrules, which will need the tools for polishing (weighted pucks of correct pitch diameter, fibre cleaver, paper grips, cement, and the correct technique to air-polish to finish)
- Splicing pre-terminate pigtails with a fusion splicer, which will mean rental of a fusion splicer (don't buy one, unless you have a spare car to sell).

But both will need an optical tested to verify the completed fibre is actually adequate (again, sell a car to buy one), so if you're going the rental route, best to rent both a fusion splicer and the tester.

Or drill a slightly bigger hole.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Early in the previous thread I posted about making a custom edge bander for my chipboard chest-of-drawers-project. On the upside, after some fine-tuning and getting low viscosity EVA glue, I started seeing passable results. On the downside, the passable results still required manual re-gluing with an iron about 70% of the time, maybe down to 50% after I got the hang of the required speed and consistency of feeding. Still, it was a massive pain in the ass to do some 40 meters of edging this way. I also didn't have a very good setup for trimming edges with a router, did a lot of it manually with a chisel. All in all, it probably took like 10+ hours to do the edging, not including the time spent building the edge bander.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2514476
After suffering through all that and finishing the project, I went and bought a chinkshit horizontal edge bander. The vertical one I built might've been passable after some further improvements for small pieces, like the sides of drawers, but it was really hard to handle larger parts, like the top plate. It was also completely impossible to use it for banding thicker than 1mm, even 1mm was difficult. 0.5-0.7mm was alright.
This is what I then bought https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4000569137844.html and first tests went well. It's pretty fast, the bond it leaves is really strong as it applies glue on both the ABS strip and the wood, and thanks to all the big rollers you can squeeze the edge on hard, even 2mm strips stuck just fine. Will see how it holds up next time I actually have a larger amount of edges to glue. Also I will definitely build a swiveling router mount for cutting the banding, I've had it with chisels.
The steel frame was an extra layer of complication, if I had to build the same thing again, I'd either go with thinner material or just use chipboard for the whole structure. Also it's really fucking heavy.

posts.com:
I found it in the archive. Whoever made this sticky, thank you. I started woodworking recently to help with another hobby/job and the information has been extremely helpful for me.

Welcome to the woodworking general, here we discuss the working of wood and the tools and techniques of working wood. So far we tend to be mostly hand tool folk with a slant towards cabinetry and carving but all are welcome and we have some capable power tool folk amount our ranks. General carpentry question such as framing/decking/general construction seems to get a better response in the /qtddtot/ or /sqt/.

>essential /wwg/ books
Tage Frid Teaches Woodworking, gives you everything you need and shows you how to do it multiple ways from hand tools to power tools and gives you the knowledge to determine which is best, and then he teaches you how to apply what you learned. The PDF of the second book can be found in the usual places, but the other two are MIA.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561588261

Christopher Schwarz tells you everything you need to know about planes and saws and their use
Handplane Essentials
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440332983
Handsaw Essentials
Best to find this one in PDF from the usual sources, out of print and pricey!

Chris Pye wrote the book on carviing and keeps on writing them.
https://www.chrispye-woodcarving.com/

The eastern tradtion, Japanese Woodworking Tools: Their Tradition, Spirit and Use by Toshio Odate
https://www.amazon.com/dp/0941936465

Leonard Lee The Complete Guide to Sharpeninig, how to sharpen most everything.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561581259

Bob Flexner - Finishing 101, covers the common stuff, his other books cover the uncommon and go into more depth
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440308454/

Illustrated Cabinet Making by Bill Hylton, learn to design furniture that won't fall apart
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1565233697/

>essential /wwg/ tv
https://www.pbs.org/show/woodwrights-shop/
https://www.newyankee.com/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518425
I dont want to come off as a dick, i like the table. just a friendly meant hint
>How do you analyze these things in design?
me? i watch old pieces and restaurateurs on fixing old stuff and of course vintage literature. for lumber furniture there is nothing new under the sun!

Little history lesson.
The sliding dovetail was mainly used as butt joint for carcasses and shelfs racks. relatative quick, really sturdy, no glue, no drying time! and thus dismountable -> nearly all big old furniture was build with that in mind.
"relative" as in quicker than building the carcass out of a million handcut dovetails with a day forced waiting.
The second application often seen even today is as a cross bar for tabletops or stools. it prevents warping and provides a simple way of mounting to the apron, was often done with wooden nails without glue for ease of transportation.

afaik long to long grain same direction as on your table isnt not a historical application. if for example the wood swells in humid summer and without climate control (both board getting wider), the dovetail could come loose.

>>2521248
It is not difficult to do freehand with just a saw. Cut them as well as you can, clamp them down at a perfect 90 with the joints as tight as they can be then run the saw down the gap. You can also pare with a good sharp chisel to get the final fit which is what I prefer for most woods. But it is not that hard to get perfect cuts freehand, just takes some practice with a bit of scrap. People regularly do other sorts of joints and get great fits freehand but for some reason butt joints are believed difficult despite being just one cut. Dovetails in 18" wide boards for casework with their dozens of individual cuts, no problem; butt joint, IMPOSSIBLE!

If you really want a jig for cleaning this sort of work up than the miter jack is the better solution. A hand screw makes an alright improvised miter jack, a little fiddly to get both jaws lined up perfect but not so bad, snug it up and then tap them to perfection with a small hammer or scrap of wood, tighten it up fully then clamp it down and go at it with chisel or plane.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521533
>Even with my Veritas 14 TPI crosscut backsaw
The Veritas is about as poor as it can get for such cuts, excessively thin plate and too much set, generally a finely set rip tooth would be better for this. But you should be able to do it, if the cut is rough that means you are putting to much pressure, the saw is binding slightly or you are wobbling a bit side to side. If the cut is smooth at one or both ends and rough in the middle that means binding or too much pressure (with a plate so thin almost any pressure is too much), if the roughness is even across the length that means you are wobbling.

The trend in making blades as thin as possible is not as great as the marketing makes it out to be, the blade will distort too easily. Find yourself an old back saw from before the thin plate came into vogue, file it rip, put in some set and then stone out almost all of the set and you will get wonderfully smooth miters in hardwoods. Stoning out the set instead of putting in very little set will give just enough fleam (functionally the same as fleam but not really fleam) on the outside of the tooth to give a smooth cut in even many softwoods. The old saws were not thicker because they could not make thin plates, they were thicker because it made it easier to get a smooth cut, the old guys knew what they were doing, sure it cut a tiny bit slower but it meant little to no fine tuning after the cut. Ultimately, such thin plates only benefit you when cutting dovetails, everywhere else it makes things more difficult.

With my old Spear and Jackson or Marples backsaws I can cut wonderfully smooth miters all day long in beech, I can manage it with my LN saws but I have to go slower and it would be a chore with the cross cut carcass saw of theirs I have, blade is too flexible and it is thicker than the Veritas.

Acetone and isopropyl are good at killing fuel system seals. Acetone is especially dangerous since a lot of parts, including fuel tanks, are made of plastics that can be dissolved by it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
this thread inspired me to research solvents miscible with petroleum/gasoline.

a lot of people have mentioned acetone and other organic solvents. While these are not great for vehicles and can break down and foul rubber components, their impact in singular events at low concentrations (low enough to not change smell or cause suspicion) is quite negligible.

others have mentioned bleach; household liquid bleach is mostly water, which is just going to cause a car to stall and make it obvious the gas was juiced.

What you should do instead is use calcium hypochlorite, ie. pool chlorine tablets; crush it into a fine powder and stick it in.

Of course, OP shouldn't just do that willy-nilly; pure bleach will not "mix" with gasoline, rather it will react violently with the hydrocarbons, oxidizing them and creating volatile compounds and chlorine gas. If the reaction generates enough heat it will self-combust due to oxygen released as part of the reaction.

I would say, do some experimenting first, both with preparation and testing. Maybe try different concoctions out on some junk 50cc motor from a safe distance to get an idea of the presentation of the gasoline and extent of damage. Look for a ratio of gasoline-to-pool-bleach that doesn't put off too much of a bleachy smell while managing to damage internal components.

and most importantly, have fun and don't be afraid to shoot tweekers! They aren't human anyway.

posts.com:
Power, Water, Heating, Cooling, Septic.
What's the best way to handle the big five off-grid?

>Power
Hydro is king, but flowing water is uncommon. Solar is weak and requires several parts that eventually need replacement. When power is abundant you get secondary systems for heating/cooling/etc. This one is hard.

>Water
Rainwater catchment? A water tower or attic water tank for gravity fed water? Maybe an underground cistern so it won't freeze, but then you lack gravity assistance.

>Heating
Can't beat wood. A secondary system should be in place, but a wood stove provides efficient heat and a cooking surface. Easy.

>Cooling
Hardest on the list. There is no simple wood stove-esque equivalent for cooling. Geothermal has promise but it's underpowered and expensive to install.

>Septic
Dead easy. You can put in your own tanks and outhouses just fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519243
Such vague answers, you must be specific in your utilization of say "wood". ie. A masonry stove? A normal metal wood stove? Also lacking here is the actual structure these will be used in, which plays the biggest roll in them succeeding.

As this anon said >>2519257
Site location and climate are the most important factors. If you have lots of sun, you will use sun, if you have a year round flowing river you could use a wheel for power.

In my climate, northern zone 5-6

>Power
Solar likely supplemented by some wind, the goal would be to reduce all other electrical uses and be very efficient.

>Water
Well would be easiest and cheapest vs. a buried cistern

>Heating
Masonry stove to supplement passive solar gains on a well insulated south facing structure along with proper roof overhands to stop summer sun.

>cooling
Solar protection via deciduous tree cover. In the winter I could absorb sunlight and in the summer be in the shade. Passive cooling can also be achieved via clever ventilation, ie. a black painted vent pipe high above my roof with some lower hanging windows opened. If I was built into a berm, I'd consider a ground pipe to pull cool underground air.

>Septic
Would depend on the number of people in the home. 2 people, I'd probably go with a composting toilet and call it a day. Grey water can go into a makeshift septic field without a proper poop tank.

>The important thing you left out - STRUCTURE
all these systems 100% work or fail based on the structure. You wont need a high thermal mass stove if you've build a cocoon of an insulated structure, since overheating will occur. My plan would be IDEALLY something like picrel, a bermed house facing south with an array of windows on that south face for winter gains. The roof would need to be angled to shade things out in summer. Structure would be concrete with some strong interior buttresses to hold back that buried rear wall. All concrete, foam, liner and dirt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519654
For the power bank, lead batteries are not recommended since they aren't meant to be repeatedly charged and discharged in such deep cycles. Lead batteries are better for emergencies, as a backup power source. Lithium batteries (there are many kinds) can be placed in parallel in order to form a power bank, but they are much more expensive and fragile. You would need to either constantly monitor the voltage and current of the batteries in order to avoid overcharging, drawing too much current, etc. There are systems you can buy for this, but they are expensive. Solar creates DC, but you would need a device to regulate the amount of charge it delivers to the battery to avoid overcharging. The wind turbine and Sterling engine create AC, which has to be converted to DC with a rectifier in order to charge the batteries (again, device needed to protect battery from overcharging). When you're ready to use your stored power, you need a power inverter to convert DC to AC so you may use it in your home. As for the bicycle, many people have used alternators to generate electricity, but once again, it creates an irregular AC signal which has to be converted to DC and then fed into a voltage regulator that can stabilize the output voltage and charge the batteries.

Solar is not "weak", but I would recommend wind if it is available to you. Hydropower is another excellent alternative if you build a dam, even on a small river.

>place
utmost important.

>Power
it's all about costs.
first, reduce power requirements to the bare minimum (no gaming pc or large tv, use a cheap laptop, etc).
then -and only then- budget for daily power usage (both summer and winter) and estimate battery requirements.
power bank: go for large LiFePo4 batteries (cost effective, safe, durable, futureproof)
diesel generator: only as an emergency backup

>Water
reduce water requirements to a reasonable minimum
consider enough storage for water bottles (you don't want to drink rain water that traversed your packed-with-birds-poop roof)
it will take quite a contraption to collect enough rain water for daily non-drinkable usage
(in my country there are public taps all around; some people occasionally use them in the middle of the night to collect a few dozen gallons of water, taking a few hours of wait)

>Heating and Cooling
insulation will save both energy and headaches
can't beat wood...except if some Stacey complains about fumes
carefully design your kitchen, you don't want to sweat
also design for hot summer days, you don't want to regret about being unable to take advantage of wind and breeze

>Septic
tanks will fill up way faster than you may imagine. call a pro. won't be cheap
you will also need to switch to fully biodegradable cleaning products

>Extras
- design for maintainability
- mosquito nets and stuff
- don't forget safety ("never seen seriously bad weather in this area")
- "oh, there never was a burglar in this area"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I live off grid, I wouldn't say there's a single best choice for each, it depends on your personal situation and having redundant systems is superior. This is my setup for what its worth
>Power
12kw solar panels into 2x 5kw inverters into a 3kw battery inverter with 15kwh of batteries, built this way to generate as much useable power in winter, at a cost of wasted peak production in summer.
I'd like to upgrade the battery inverter and batteries at some point
petrol generator
I'd like to add wind to the mix, but am not sure what size I should get or how I should wire it into the rest of the system
>Water
rainwater
springwater
either source is pumped up to tanks above the house that provide pressure via gravity. I've only ever used the springwater during a bad drought. Glad it is there though.
>Heating
fireplace
woodfired oven
electric blankets
I live in Australia, the winters don't get cold enough to run the fireplace except for a few of the coldest days of the year, the woodfired oven is what we mostly use as it provides cooking and hot water as well as heating.
>Hot water
gets its own mention
I have 3 ways of getting hot water
water jacket on the wood-fired oven
instant gas system
excess solar feeds into a hot water tank, 8 months out of the year we generate enough solar for this
>Cooling
ceiling and pedestal fans
>Septic
Aerated wastewater treatment system
backup: shit in a hole/bucket

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

PLA+ won't matter vs PLA for heat resistance. Either would be fine up to at least 230F after annealing. HTPLA will warp at least 5x less during the anneal. Just slowly ramp up the heat in hot water during the anneal, bonus if you pack in sand or plaster prior. It won't melt when hot but it will get softer, kinda like when you steam wood so you can bend it.

>>2518263
superslicer/prusaslicer IIRC should do like 120% flow on the first layer. Just keep your plate clean with alcohol before every print. Some prints are just hard to get good adhesion and need a brim. If your cooling is shit you'll end up with curling which will snag the nozzle.

>ender 3 V2
It has a touchscreen though. In my experience touchscreens are always worse than just the basic blue LCD with the little wheel, because the touch sensor sucks and the firmware is really limited compared to the Marlin you can run on the older style printers. For example on my Ender 3 with ABL I can start a print from my computer and then tune the z offset up or down while it lays out the skirt before starting the first layer, to make sure I get perfect adhesion. On my Ender 5, I have to start a print, cancel, adjust the z offset in increments of 0.1 (which is asinine because for perfect adhesion and quality without elephant's foot you want to be within 0.02 of the correct height), and if I need to tune it more I have to start and stop the print again. Based on the picture it doesn't even look like they've added a second print cooling fan, it's still just blowing from one direction, it just has an ugly plastic cover over the print head instead of the plain black metal one on the old Ender. The only actual improvement I can see is that it actually comes with a glass bed now instead of just the glued on buildtak clone that wears out after five prints, but knowing Creality that glass is curvier than that maker slut they hired to promote the CR-30.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520874
Bought the creality 0.5W laser. The power is definitely lacking, but even then if it had decent focus it would still be usable for what I want (burning away thin etch-resistant coatings). But my laser does not have decent focus, getting the beam small enough to really ablate coatings is a tricky task, but charring wood is definitely doable. I may have to 3D print a lens-holder with more degrees of freedom, or just go for a fibre-coupled laser or Nd:YAG. A more expensive laser like that 1.6W may well be higher quality.

10W is a fair bit for engraving, and it will easily burn away thin coatings like aluminium anodising, paint, PCB solder mask, etc.

Watch out though, the third party software availability for turning a 3D printer into a laser is kinda shit. Lightburn is almost certainly the way to go, but it's not FOSS. Creality have their own (windows only) software. I've tried a web-tool, which has major errors and doesn't raster, and an addon for inkscape, which has major scale issues and doesn't raster. In my case I want vector outlines AND rastered insides, I hope lightburn can do so. There's a free trial that I'll get around to using one of these days.

>>2519724
You still haven't given up? The problem is most likely jfet biasing. Without resistor to ground from gate you're relying on whatever crap like flux residue and balls sweat you put on the capsule to get some magical path to ground. Its just fundamentally a horrible design.
>I even built the whole circuit in falstad and it works flawlessly there
This means that your circuit model is probably shit and doesn't represent reality very well, you're missing some key parameter that you're not modeling - AC source is not accurate representation of capsule, not even close. You need to focus more on how capsule works (modeling, expected impedances and output values at different sound levels) and how jfet works (biasing types, operating ranges, tolerance ranges, gain, parasitics). You can either learn about those things (plenty of resources on the internet) or just throw everything in the bin and buy a commercial microphone - now you know that you aren't just paying for component cost, you're also paying for guaranteed specifications, testing and EMC. Manufacturers aren't ripping people off for no reason.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519818
>well the original design doesn't have one
Exactly. As I said they're relying on flux or cum crusts, dust, humidity and other parasitic paths to ground. There are special microphone JFETs that don't require external resistors because they have integrated diodes that act as resistors. Normal JFETs don't have them and you must provide a reliable path to ground. Some people might be lucky and have enough parasitics to do the job, but that's not reliable engineering.
>10k should be fine?
10k is too little, you need at least 1meg and even that will take away some low end response so something like 10meg-1g would be appropriate, but again that's why you need to know your capsule, how it works and what are its parameters.

For PSU filtering they’re probably fine. But for DC-blocking AC-pass capacitors, or other signal filtration capacitors, you’ll likely want to avoid them. MLCCs like that can suffer from microphonicity and voltage-dependant capacitance, and they’re all somewhat prone to PCB deformation causing distortion. Unless you know they’ve got the right dielectric for your purposes, that is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520698
Standard motors (excluding stepper motors) aren’t designed to run in stall-condition continuously, they draw significantly higher current when not rotating. So either use a stepper motor, or run any other kind of motor significantly below its rated voltage. You can do ohm’s law calculations using the DC resistance to check that the stall current when undervolted would have it dissipate a normal amount of heat.

Undervolting a motor naturally means it will be larger than it would otherwise need to be, a stepper may be more space efficient.

you can do this with a motor that includes a clutch.
the motor spins continually, but the load can vary from zero to full speed.
you control it by passing a DC current thru the clutch coil.

how you control the clutch is for you to determine:
- maybe using pressure switches, or magnetic switches
- maybe the making of electrical contact between the 2 parts
- maybe on a timer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520768
MOSFETs act in the ohmic region when fully switched on, and have a normal positive tempco, so running them in parallel is fine. Usually you give them seperate gate resistors from what I've seen, but you may want to look into that since I'm not sure it makes sense. If switching losses are an issue you may even want to use seperate gate drivers, as to not split gate drive current up too much.
Saw a welder with like 16 IRF540s in parallel on TPAI's youtube channel, which was kinda funny.

>I can't see how he can do this without parallel power FETs
I'm also designing a simlilarly powerful motor controller, running on 12S lipos, though only to half the current since I'll be driving two wheels. Assuming it's still in stock, I plan on using the TPW1R306PL MOSFET by Toshiba, it's rated at 100A continuous, though in reality that's a function of heat-sinking. It's a real modern part with the ability to strap a heat-sink directly on top of it, that can operate up to 175C. Assuming 25C ambient, that's ∆T=150C, and it has 0.93C/W thermal resistance to a heat-sink atop it. I plan on using 6 of them (BLDC) with a 1C/W heat-sink, so that's 6C/W when split up, 7C/W total when including the FET itself, meaning maximum of 21W. The FET's gate resistance gets up to 2mΩ at 175C, so through P = R*I^2 we get I = √(P/R) = √(21/0.002) = 102A. So yeah it's possible, arguably even cheaper than parallel FETs.
There are better MOSFETs out there, but they don't have the upper thermal pad, so you'd only get that kind of performance if you mount them to an aluminium-backed PCB. Which is arguably worth doing, but note that JLC only does single-sided aluminium-backed boards, so getting your entire driver circuit on there is more or less infeasible. I think PCBway or someone else does multi-sided ones.

>>2520716
A gear-motor can provide more torque at lower power wasted than a direct-drive motor. You'd still need to undervolt them to prevent overheating when stalled, but the higher torque may be a requirement. Some stepper-motors are optimised for high stall torque.
It may be worth hooking them up to a smart power supply so the motor is driven at its full rated voltage when rotating, and undervolted when detecting a stall condition. That way it isn't really slow when rotating freely, which may be an issue especially with a gear-motor. On a brushed DC motor this could be done with a simple current-limiting SMPS. With a brushless or stepper motor, some sort of current or position sensor would be fed to the ESC (via a microcontroller?) to tell it to reduce the duty-cycle.

>>2520786
It needs to be able to provide stall torque, not just stop. Dumping that power into the clutch may not be something it's rated for.

posts.com: Hello. Which OPamp would best be used with pic related equalizer? https://sound-au.com/articles/eq.ht<wbr>m

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520895
Any op-amp designed for audio use, like an OPA2134. TL074s are pretty common too. I recommend EEVblog's video on jellybean op-amps. You may want to check the noise specs to ensure your signal is staying significantly above the noise floor for a given input amplitude. Also specs like common-mode input range, slew-rate, etc. could be handy to check depending on the signal input, but generally a line-level audio signal isn't going to get anywhere near the limits of a common op-amp on those.

Should go without saying but that circuit wants a split-rail power supply. ±5 to ±18 is usually what you're aiming for, but some op-amps (especially JFET-input op-amps) want a wider range rather than a smaller range. Best to use an iron transformer-based power supply with linear regulators and sufficiently large caps. If you absolutely have to use a switching power supply (can be very noisy with audio circuits) then ensure you tie the ground rail to protective earth, and try to use LC filters or capacitive multipliers or zener-pass regulators on the power rails to block that noise. Common linear regulators are bad at blocking high-frequency ripple.

posts.com:
>>2520982
If you're using it closed-loop anyhow, (e.g. can trim for error with the MCU) you could just add a series resistor from the DAC. But that still outputs current as a function of the difference between the voltage on either side of the resistor, so it won't be floating unless you use even more MCU feedback, which might not be fast enough. A single op-amp design would also not be floating.

If you need a floating converter then yeah a circuit like >>2521053 is probably necessary. Would be easy to adjust it for ±1mA, just change the key resistance values, swapping the 10M for 1k should work I think. With such a low resistor you may be able to get away without the buffering bottom op-amp. The ripple-dampening network (1k,100Ω,10nF) is a requirement, though values will depend on your situation.
That schematic is a split-rail design though, so you'll likely want to use a 4th op-amp to buffer a 50/50 voltage divider between 5V and 0V.

>>2520994
Mate he wants a variable current ranging from -1mA to 1mA. Your wanky LM317 circuits can't do that.

>>2521082
ESP32s, probably.

>>2521139
Could likely get standard headphones to work if you used an extremely wound transformer. Like 100:1 or 1000:1. Crystal earpieces are capacitive though, so you'll probably need to get that post-detection capacitance from somewhere. Otherwise the high-frequency shit might mess with the transformer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519047
a 1/8" kerf is nothing like a dado.

Thecreason freehanding a rotary cutting tool that *is* dimensionally proportioned like a dado is because the wider the cut you are plowing, the less longitudinal stability there is and the easier it becomes for the side-to-side direction to swap with front-to-rear if the thrust angle shifts even slightly.
Its the same reason Jeeps get less stable in forward motion the closer the track width gets to the wheelbase length and will flip easily at speed, and why top fuel dragsters are long and very skinny...the former turns off its path almost by itself and the latter is designed to not turn except for tiny corrections to keep it going straight.
A freehand dado set is like putting a 10,000hp dragster engine in a Suzuki Samurai, it will go sideways the second it hooks up.

>>2519127
>if i cinch the nut on real tight wouldn't it be functionally equivalent to a 1/8" wheel?

Yeah, underneath the nut and washer...but at the rim there's nothing to hold them together and despite what your intuition is telling you those discs can and do distort out of plane in use, ESPECIALLY ones that thin.
I've watched diamond blades twice that thick distort nearly 1/4" out of plane when hogging out super hard material, the heat makes them go all rubbery.
Stacking thin ones *might* not end in disaster but it might also be worse, doing it like >>2518878 says won't take more than a few seconds longer and is less likely to wobble or disintegrate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519664
>i don't see how multiple discs side-by-side would have less lateral strength then a single disc.

I never said that; I said that the friction of plowing a wider cut creates more and different forces and heat generation on the cutting tool, that tend to work againt it running straight and true.
You seem convinced that stacking discs together and tightening the arbor nut really hard will be enough to make the assembled discs capable of resisting those forces without distorting or losing alignment in the kerf, but there's no merit in that assumption and lots of reasons to expect the opposite based on real world experience and physics.
For example: those discs generate heat, and are designed to dissipate it safely when the tool feed/ rotation speed is normal. Thiickness is part of that calculation and affects the ratio of mass to cooling surface area, which is why they're thin to begin with.
If you stack three discs you've cut down that exposed cooling surface on the outer discs by 1/2 and by 100% on the middle one.
Put another way, you've tripled the kerf width/material removed, tripled the mass of the cutting tool, but still only have the same number of exposed disc sides to bleed the heat off.
On top of that, since that mass isn't one homogenous piece the heat in the center 1/3 can't dissipate as readily and is effectively insulated against maximum heat transfer by the gaps between it and the outer discs.
So the center disc will heat up more and faster and lose rigidity, and the outer discs will be unevenly heated which invites warping in the direction of spreading apart since heat expands and its concentrated on their inner faces.
1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520360
2/2

Steel is not wood or something brittle like masonry or stone that will chip out in any gaps created when the discs distort that way, and any distortion whether from thermal expansion or the feed angle getting off line will always act to spread the discs apart.

It's not a table saw or a milling machine, they don't use super thin cutters stacked together for a reason, even when they have rock solid feed/guide mechanisms to keep everything straight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521020
>how
Mechanically or electrically.
Electrically will involve practically reprogramming the motor controller. While it is barely possible to reverse engineer the system, it's not at all practical.
The manufacturer, however, may already have a different firmware that does exactly this. Because if they don't already sell your unit to physical therapy offices, they probably sell a similar model with the same board. Write to them with an appropriate sob story. Or try to find someone who repairs gym equipment with same.
If the motor is not direct drive on the shaft, you may have a belt or chain to play with. Smaller motor gear to larger treadwheel gear means slower treadmill. But also higher torque, so make double sure your safety stops work.

Air compressors and pneumatic tools in general are an underrated kind of scary. Most people do not pay them much mind, but you can have all sorts of crazy shit flying off at mach speed if you're not careful or if the tools has not been maintained. So many people do not drain their tanks and the corrosion just builds and builds. If your pressures are wonky, you can get a hose fly back really hard if you don't man-handle the connectors when you release them. Easy way to lose your front teeth to some brass. Most people bypass the safety on their nailguns, too. So you've got potential live-fire going who knows where on a good bump to a gun or something like that.

As a carpenter, the table saw is probably the most scary tool I use. They can turn into a fucking crossbow-spear launcher if somebody doesn't know what they're doing. Otherwise, I think idiots on the work-site are more scary than tools. Always gotta watch your back when you're working with other people, they won't give a fuck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2501226
>Concrete blocks only.

Blocks frequently shatter from the point loading of vehicles so at least use a wood shim, but for stability it's hard to beat scrap rims (tens of thousands of cars in salvage yards sit atop stacked rims tack welded to each other or nested). A solid block is one thing but "cinder blocks" break easily.

Rims work in sand or gravel. You can nest small inside large. You can shim with wood cribbing (I save my drain oil then soak wood blocks in the bucket, they'll last well over a decade outdoors.

If you want to store a vehicle the u-pull-it method of rims beneath each corner ahead of the rear axles and behind the front is highly stable. You can't knock the vehicle over except with a fork lift.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2506081
>but it’s annoying replacing them. Also I hate safety goggles.

Face shields like Jackson (your local welding supply should stock them so you can try 'em on) are far better because goggles do not protect the face. Buy one spare for when the first gets scratched but they last a long time if you hang them up after use.

4.5" cutting discs are unfortunate. I mod or replace the guards on any 4.5" grinder I score used and only buy 6" grinders to use the much longer lasting 6" discs which also have much faster edge speed. I've cut 3/8' and 1/2" steel plate with them and severed truck axles. The larger grinders can run 4.5" attachments too of course like flap discs.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2500970
Like the name suggests, the mash pot is the steel pot in which you heat up your water+grains.
Sparge water is pre-heated water that you use to rinse off the grains after taking them out. So when your mashing ends and you lift your mash-basket / brew bag to let it drain, there's still a lot of sugars attached to the wet grains. So you slowly rinse the grains with the hot sparging water to wash out the remaining sugars. The magic behind it is to use as much water as necessary but as less water as possible, because if you use too much water, you're lowering your OG again.

>The OG is off at first and then I add water until it falls within the range (which is what the instructions say). But that never brings it up to more than 4.5 gallons and sometimes it's barely 4 gallons.
That means that your brewhouse efficiency is too low, so either you're doing something wrong while mashing, or the grains in the brew kits are of low quality.
If you're mashing at a too low temperature, the alpha and beta amylases don't have enough time to convert the starches into sugars, if your mashing temperature is too high, the amylases create a lot of unfermentable sugars.
What is your brew set-up? Do you use an automatic electric brew-kettle, or a diy solution? Do you use the iodine test at the end of mashing to check on remaining starches?

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2501480
In a normal batch of mead or fruitwine, without nutrients, over 50% of the pitched yeast is dead after 3 days. That's absolutely normal as the apoptosis of the yeast will serve as a nutrient-dispenser for the younger yeast generation. After that the amount of live yeast will drop exponentially.
With yeast nutrients the same amount of dead yeast is only reached after 5 days, that's 2 more days of healthy sugar conversion at the time of highest activity after yeast-pitching. And what's the effort to get that? Like opening a bag and putting a teaspoon full of powder into your fermenter?
>If you go to work the next two days, you'll get double the pay
>Nah, fuck that, I'm too lazy. Also I never used that and my bank account has been fine
Whatever tickles your fancy. Sometimes I wish we had unique identifiers on here like they use on /pol/. That way I'd know if you're the next guy crying on here that his fermentation is stuck.

>but I subsequently read an article someone(you?) posted about yeast autolysis/apoptosis as a "scorched earth" way of feeding its own lineage while poisoning other strains of yeast.
Yeah, that was me. The apoptosis caused by "natural causes" (Which is still not fully understood scientifically) is a genetic program inside the yeast that tells it "You're old enough, time to die", so the yeast cell dies and decomposes into substances that work as nutrients for the other cells.
Only if the cause of death is not "natural", the apoptosis triggers the "Scorched Earth" mode and the cell decomposes into the different toxic proteins.
Fact is, that in most cases a stuck fermentation is caused by missing yeast nutrients.
I wanted to try out Fermaid-O just to check on how it works and if it makes a difference to the Kitzinger yeast nutrients that I'm using but when I saw the price, I said fuck it.
>Kitzinger = 83.90€/kg
>Fermaid = 371.33€/kg

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2501686
It won't be the next Amateur Brew-Off Champion but it'll be a challenge to get the best out of nothing.

>Diastatic Malt
Diastatic means that it contains active enzymes which are able to convert the starches into sugars. That means you'll definitely get a wort out of this.
My definite recommendation would be to closely keep to the resting times:
Protease Resting: 10-20 min. @54°C (Proteins will be broken down to create free amino nitrogens which work as yeast nutrients)
Maltose Resting: 30-90 min. @62°C (Polysaccharides will be broken down into maltose by beta-amylase, that's your source for fermentable sugar)
Mashout: 15-45 min. @71°C (Polysaccharides will be broken down into dextrin by alpha-amylase which will bring aroma, flavor and mouth-feeling)
I'd especially recommend the mashout, since we don't know what kind of flavor your malt will bring into the game. Make sure that your brewing setup is capable of raising the temperature at least 1°C per minute to ensure fast switches between the rests. And don't omit the Protease Rest, as the CEO of Yeast Nutrients I'll know if you do.

>Distillers yeast
Don't use that, get some bakers yeast instead. Distillers yeast is especially bred for really high alcohol tolerances (18-21%ABV) without regards for losses, which especially shows in aroma and flavor, most mashes with distillers yeast have no proper flavor at all.

>Cheapest hop brand hops
We can figure something out with this, as long as you know the alpha-acid contents of your hops.
You need to define first what kind of beer you're aiming for, how many IBUs, how much hops in the flavor and how much in the aroma. Smell your hops and see for yourself if you want that aroma in your beer. If not, then you should omit late additions. If you're boiling for 60 minutes and you want bitterness and flavor, then add @60 mins. and @30 mins. Make sure that you measure the amounts properly and remember that the total amount will decide about the final IBUs.

You can't maximize CO2 production, the produced CO2 is proportional to the produced ethanol.

>>2502932
I don’t think cold crashing alone will solve that, it doesn’t kill or filter all living yeasts. Pasteurise or k meta or wait for sugar to run out. My experience with sorbate isn’t too good either btw. As in I put 4x the recommended dose once and still had live yeast left.

Pasteurisation is really easy if its in bottles already. Put a coaster in a big pan, put bottles in, and 1 bottle of water. Top pan up with hot water, put thermometer in water bottle, turn on stove, wait for desired temperature + duration. Doesn’t affect taste if you stay under 80C/175F. The coaster prevents the glass from touching the pan which could overheat the bottom.

Anyway for cold crashing just put fridge on low setting and leave bottles in overnight

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2502932
>but it won't stop fermenting
Is it really fermenting or is it just releasing all the CO2 that was previously solved in solution?
You can rack it into a large pot and with a large spoon stir it gently to get the CO2 out (at least 5 minutes), then rack it into your jug again.
If you're taking gravity readings you can check if it's really fermenting. In the past 10 years I had a handful of batches fail, one of them I remember because it was the first and up til now only bacterial infection I got. It was foamlessly bubbling for weeks in a manner like the surface of a freshly poured glass of mineral water looks. Gravity never changed and the batch continued to bubble for 3 weeks until the gas leaving the airlock started to smell stale and musty and suddenly the flavor turned just abysmally bad. A wine cooper friend of mine then diagnosed the bacterial infection from my description.

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2503511
What will be the main thing you'll brew with it?
A lot of people make a fetish out of temperature control, in my opinion that's only necessary in specialty beers (e.g. Saison) and if you have not a single place on hand with a stable temperature environment.
If you have a cellar or basement with a constant temperature in the operating range of your yeast, you won't need temperature control on your fermenter.
In the end it's a nice to have but not something I'd waste 600 bucks for.
Just as a comparison, the 30 liter stainless steel fermenter from Brew Monk has a port for temperature probe (Probe with digital thermometer pre-installed), only costs 199.95€ and you can even get a chiller for that fermenter for 89.95€.
Those of course don't offer the functionality of being a keg and a fermenter in one, but for the money you saved, you can get 3 normal kegs on top.

https://brouwland.com/en/fermentation-vessels/660-brew-monk-stainless-steel-fermenter-30-l.html

Measuring the specific gravity should help you know when the yeast are about spent and not liking the alcohol solution strength anymore. If it stops going down then they aren't using the sugar additions. If you can get your hands on some sorbate or something like that you should be able to shut them down pretty good. If alcohol is ill eagle in a country and someone is home brewing to get around that they might as well go all the way and distill. Doesn't even have to be fancy. Any home canner or pressure cooker is readily converted to churn out some kind of spirit and if you're even a little handy brazing ain't too hard. In the US we can try bluffing and say it's all for beer if caught and they'll probably drop it. I don't know of any good excuses for possessing equipment like this if muh beer isn't an option.
As for getting a lot of yeast when transferring I think you need a second vessel. Transfer from first bucket to second once fermentation has decreased activity. In this second vessel the yeast should fall out and will yield clearer bottles. If you're made of money you can always find a way to run it through a filter. I don't know how to go about doing this without a keg to pressurize and push the solution through it. There must be some kind of way to use gravity without too much oxygen exposure though. Still, at that point it's easiest to just rack to a second or even third bucket with time in between for yeasties to drop down to the bottom.

> Does gray mold damage ceramics?
Depends, if it’s intact glazed ceramics then no but a lot can happen if something finds it’s way into small cracks or under the glazing

> Additionally, is cleaning the mold out and wiping with soap and vinegar enough?
No

> Or does it require some speshul ritualistic cleansing
Yes. Mold spores are very resilient and vinegar may not reach all of them inside small cracks or scratches. You could boil them out at 90C but have to be sure that the ceramic is heated through and through. Quaternary ammonium cation is a common spore killer but works by leaving a small reactive film that will probably kill yeasts too. Would probably use heat as it’s the only thing that you can be sure reaches every spot, but it may not even be worth it if it’s a cheap old scratched jar

posts.com:
>>2516195
>Reminded me a bit of how mae homemade Glögg
Glögg is just a fortified mulled wine, no fermentation involved.

Looking at the ingredients it indeed sounds like a really intense spicy/earthy brew which could use a higher alcohol content.

But this anon >>2515733 is correct, you'll end up with about 860g sugar per liter which is enough to create about 44% ABV if the average yeast wouldn't die under the osmotic pressure of 420g sugar per liter or around 22% ABV. (Or even sooner, depending on strain)

With 250 - 280g sugar per liter you'll reach 12.8 - 14.3% ABV and the osmotic pressure is low.
So you should use 875 - 980g sugar in total for your brew.

Just remember the basics:
>Sanitize your equipment
>Use an airlock
>Give it time (12.8 - 14.3% ABV can take 4-6 weeks to dry fermentation)

posts.com:
>>2516720
Low tech recipe:
Blend apples with 1tbsp of water per apple. I use a kitchen blender. Strain through cheesecloth, keep pulp in juice to a minimum. Add sugar or preservative free honey (if needed) while heating. You get ≈5% abv from the apple juice plus ≈1% per 20g/L of added sugar. Don’t cook it, but pasteurise. Let it cool to room temp and let yeast warm to room temp. Put juice in carboy, add a few tsp yeast on top, close carboy but not air tight (or preferably, with airlock) and let sit. Wait 2-4 weeks or so until no more bubbles appear, then 1 more. Siphon into clean carboy/bottles, wait two weeks, siphon again. If there’s a residue at the bottom, repeat once more. Taste will slowly get better from around 5 weeks after first siphoning.

Most important keep everything sterile/sanitised. Carboy, tools, funnels, hoses, bottles, airlock etc. Boiling water works most of the time, Star San is better and doesn’t burn your hands. Use brewers yeast not bread yeast.

>>2518235
> it should foam for like a week, but it's only the second day and the foam on mine is completely gone
Foam is mostly initial stages when yeast is growing very fast. Depends on nutrients how long foam lasts, shorter/longer may be a good or a bad sign. If sugar is very low, foaming is more visible than with high sugar. I usually get between 2 and 5 days.

> There's no sediment or visible layers so far. Is it fine or is it bad?
Did you put enough yeast? The yeast grows, the healthy yeast get suspended/float up and down. The dead yeast stay at the bottom as sediment. If the yeast can’t grow for some reason, you’ll only have very little of it

> It still bubbles good through the airlock and has a decent and fairly strong fruity wine smell
As long as it’s bubbling, it’s fermenting. But it may take longer if your yeast isn’t in great shape.

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2517336
>>2517416
Your "personal experience" and your White Labs fart smelling kit doesn't prove shit.
Bakers yeast is Saccharomyces, exactly as brewers yeast, wine yeast or distillery yeast and it will perform just great with alcohol tolerances up to 12 %ABV depending on manufacturer. (e.g. Dr. Oetker in Germany and surrounding countries, Fleischmann in the US and Canada) The main part in flavoring the
>Beer
is the malt
>Wine
is the fruit/honey
while the yeast contributes nothing more than a "direction" the flavor takes, a kind of signature finger-snapping. Let's just make ye olde English Brown Ale with bakers yeast for the sake of it:
Will it have exactly that distinct, classic Brown Ale flavor? No, very most liekely not.
Will it taste like a good and proper dark beer? Hell yes, it will, because the malt will already contribute 90% of the flavor.
The only distinction that I allow in this discussion is that bakers yeast tends to not settle into a compact sediment-cake at the bottom after fermentation is done but will stay in a loosely, floaty state at the bottom of the fermenter, but that has nothing to do with the flavor.

Fun fact: Most breweries fucking 1000 years ago in the Germanic/Bohemian regions got their yeast from surrounding bakeries. Specialty yeasts just became a thing when brewers started to breed their yeasts to save on cost only later they realized that their yeast strain gave their beer that signature flavor. Was it proper beer before they reached their signature flavor? Yes it was.

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients

>>2521220
Distillers yeast is Saccharomyces, so it works as well as all other yeast strains when it comes to creating alcohol.
But one thing that strains declared as distillers yeast have in common is, that they are bred for maximum alcohol tolerance without regards to losses, which makes them a really bland strain. They don't create any special aromas and no distinct flavor profile.
If that's what you're after, then it's perfectly fine to continue to use them. If you're trying to create a certain flavor profile, or you want to increase the amount of Glycerin produced, then you should start to try out some other strains.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2520523
>also my kitchen scale is only accurate to 1 gram so if i lost 3 grams that might actually be 2,6 or 3,4 grams
Btw resolution and accuracy/repeatability is not the same. Cheap digital kitchen scales will easily give you a few grams difference depending on which side you put the weight on and how flat your table is, there's also temperature drift and god knows what else. Professional lab scales are routinely calibrated with standard weights and use thermally stabilized circuitry to achieve their accuracy, which you won't find in battery powered kitchen scales. I test mine regularly with a 2kg weight and they give me results different by like 5 grams throughout the week even though repeated measurements side by side are within 1 gram usually. You really want scales with 0.1g or better precision if you want to hunt down single grams accurately.

>>2521249
>At sizes this small a reciprocating engine will be more efficient than a turbine.
An atmospheric steam engine is 10-15% efficient whereas a gas turbines get around 20%-30% (1-2 bars gauge pressure). I'd guess the two are about equivalent in terms safety. Large steam turbines in power plants get 55% efficiency, but they are using pressures of 100 bars.

>>2521273
Turbine engines run off the Brayton cycle (see picrel >>2520658) which basically compresses the air and fuel in a static combustion chamber which could be loaded with solid fuels without a problem. Solids in a typical Otto (gas) or Diesel engine would bend the connecting rods among other issues. However, pistons could still replace the compressor and turbine in a gas turbine engine to achieve higher pressures, and thus run more efficiently. Another possibility is to have an Otto or Diesel engine where the cylinder is connected via the cylinder head to a separate combustion chamber for the coal, but the chamber's volume would negatively affect the compression ratio. Thus an engine running coal would be significantly larger than an engine running off liquid fuels for the same efficiency (but also more powerful).

>>2521296
But they're less efficient or they risk melting the exterior walls. At the end of the day, turbine is simpler.

I am not fixated on turbines per se, but rather any engine that operates off of the Brayton cycle, of which gas turbines are the most well known. I would probably choose a Quasiturbine rotary over a turbine for as compressing the intake air would help cool the rotor, which is perfectly fine for efficiency and an engine that doubles as a furnace.

>lol. lmao even. yeah if you're happy with an almost non-existant efficiency maybe

Steam is going to need a turbine, rotary, or piston as well. I guarantee for any one that you select for a steam engine, it will run better on the Brayton cycle, because:
1. It will capture the work done by the exhaust gas.
2. It will burn more completely (especially if the boiler is quenching combustion).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521413
>that's why i find it a bit bizarre you're suggesting solid fuels to directly feed into a turbine
I'm actually proposing using a cyclone separator between the combustor and turbine.

>so far i haven't found any commercial applications of this
Since almost any existing gas turbine could be retrofitted with a feed tube and cyclone separator without a major drop in efficiency, the only reason why a solid fuel turbine hasn't gone commercial is a lack of imagination/foresight and herd mentality. You might as well ask why haven't we found an application for gas turbines. The answer is that gas turbines aren't as efficient as piston engines or large steam turbines.
>every power plant that burns solid fuels uses a rankine cycle, why is that?
Because these are plants with large engines and millions of dollars of funding behind them. The problem with steam is it doesn't scale down well. Small steam engines running at high pressures isn't feasible. Even if you can contain a boiler explosion in the exhaust stream, you still have to get inside to rebuild the boiler. It is much more feasible to raise the compression ratio of an IC engine.
>Brayton cycle is nothing special.
It's not other than being the only cycle that allows for a static combustion chamber in an IC engine, which is beneficial for utilizing solid fuels. There's also nothing preventing us now from raising the pressure ratio on a solid fuel engine.

The Brayton cycle also has a potential to be applied to furnaces to increase their thermal efficiency and performance. So anyone interested in developing any kind engine should take interest in the Brayton cycle.

>looks like a discount wankel engine
It's better than the Wankel. Wankel is limited to 3:1 compression ratio, whereas there is no limit to the compression ratio of the Quasiturbine.
http://quasiturbine.promci.qc.ca/ETheoryQTVersusWankel.htm

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2517641
>what's the point of running a .6mm nozzle?
A 0.4mm nozzle can print layers up to 0.3mm tall. A 0.6mm can print layers up to 0.45mm thicc. But it's not just time saved by printing thicker layers. You can also cut down on the number of perimeters since the thicker the nozzle, the wider it will extrude. Obviously this all comes at the cost of fine detail, but IRL, it's pretty fucking hard to tell the quality difference between 0.4 and 0.6.

Printing with a wider nozzle will also create stronger prints. Prints are basically layers of plastic string lightly molten together, they delaminate relatively easily. A wider nozzle means the "string" the print is made from is wider, which is more rigid (because you need less layers).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518043
Two things
1) clean the plate and don't touch it with your fingers the oils decrease adhesion
2) turn your hotend and bed up to printing temp, send it home an all axes, so you should be at Z0.0 then go into your movement menu and raise Z by .2mm (or whatever distance you have a matching shim for) then whip out your 0.2mm shim and level with it until the shim just barely drags under the nozzle when perfectly flat against the bed. Do every corner (well not actually the corner, best results are directly above the screw your adjustment knob turns) in sequence, twice.

Now your set up so that when your slicer tells your print head to move to Z0.16 or Z97.82 you will be exactly that distance, not a slip of paper off of those distances.

With this done you will have less trouble figuring out / calibrating other settings in your slicer like initial layer height and flow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518043
Forgot to ask what machine you are using? The ender 3's and some other printers have a Z Axis screw on one side of the bed and mere rollers on the other side so it just kinda hangs or sags, which isn't so bad cause your bed levelling will compensate for it being out of square (not really but your layers can still be parallel with the bed because you've levelled the bed to be parallel with your gantry arm in all its sagging out of square glory). It's pretty easy to either have the rollers on that floating side be too loose or too tight.

If too loose it gets floppy but still kinda usable. It'll burn out the Z stepper faster tho.

If too tight it can be an issue if it's also dirty by causing it to be a little stubborn. If there is debris on the column or stuck to the wheels it will occasionally require a slightly larger movement to get past the crap that's in the way of the rollers, this leaves your print head slightly higher or lower than it should be. This is a big deal unless your laying down some thicc .5 mm layer heights with a big phat nozzle. Occasionally stubborn z movements on normal layer heights will ruin your repeatability and causing poor adhesion sometimes but not others. Try cleaning the column and rollers, give the roller bearings a little shot of lubricant if they aren't sealed. With a finger gently apply a small lifting pressure to the floating end, if it moves easily it's too loose. Adjust as needed. It's better to be a little too tight than a little too loose.

like regardless of how much plastic i force out the nozzle into the first layer (within reason), the "ceiling" ought to be exactly the height between the plate and the nozzle.

it's kind of hard to explain what i'm trying to say. look at pic. the red outer layer is first, then the inner part of green (moving outwards in a circle), then yellow.
imagine i'm pushing out like 50% more plastic than is needed to fill the volume.
so the green is bound by the red "skin". when i do the first inside green wall, it spreads out further than it ought to. the line is wider than .4mm or whatever.
then when i do the next "outer" green ring, the nozzle melts some of that previous extra wide line and as the plastic is extruded, it displaces the previous line upwards slightly.
like you could imagine a trough and you're laying a bead in the center, the liquid plastic isn't going to be compressed, the nozzle is going to melt the outer walls a bit and the new bead is going to force the outer walls up slightly.
and i think that means that each layer is not flat. its flat with some raised spots in between each line. and that error is carried upwards through each layer.
even though the next layer starts exactly where it should vertically, the lower layer has more plastic than it should, and that propagates upwards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518743
You need to compile your own Marlin. There's a setting in the source code for how many points to probe, you can probably probe hundreds of points if you feel like wasting time. Honestly probing nine points is fine for 200x200mm, I use that on my Ender and it's fine. Creality use sixteen IIRC.
It's not as bad as it sounds, but I haven't done it in years because once you have a working firmware you basically never want to touch it again. If you have an older printer you can open the Marlin source code in the Arduino IDE, make your changes, and flash it to the printer directly. If you have a newer printer you need to use VSCode with some extension and compile into a binary on your computer. You then need to open the hidden folder it for some reason saves the compiled file to, copy that to your SD card, and restart the printer with the card plugged in. It'll automatically flash the firmware. You can verify by plugging the SD card into your PC again and checking if the firmware file changed name, if it did that means it successfully loaded.
Hope that helped.

Can't remember which of you was having issues with wonky layer widths resulting in weird overextrusion problems, but go find a 3D model test print with a name something like "0.4 mm wall test" or whatever. The model should be a squat box with no bottom and no roof - just the walls exactly .4 mm thick or just choose one that matches your nozzle width. Check your print settings and make sure line width is set to exactly match. Print. Measure. Then adjust your flow until it's printing walls within .02 of the line width in your settings. Don't measure the elephant's foot, ignore it or print on a raft for these test prints.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518967
.01mm usually accepted in printer settings but not really. Ender 3's only let you, while at the machine, manually adjust the height in increments of 0.1mm but even that is stupid.
Most steppers on printers have 200 steps in one rotation and z screws of a particular pitch so the single step resolution is 0.04mm so all your z-height settings should be a multiple of that for most consistent results but some motor/controller combos apply partial voltages to achieve partial steps. Good luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519000
Marlin is a repo you download from github. In it are folders with premade configs for a whole bunch of printers, unless you bought something super weird there'll be a premade config for your printer there. Copy the config files from the template folder into the actual folder (github has instructions somewhere IIRC) and make the changes you need/want, then compile.
https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin Marlin repo
https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Configurations Premade configs
https://marlinfw.org/docs/basics/install.html Marlin official documentation
Arduino IDE can do 8-bit control boards, PlatformIO can do any control boards. If your printer updates firmware via SD card you want PlatformIO, otherwise you want Arduino.

3D printers sit on that intersection between DIY and mechatronics where you're expected to both be reasonably handy and tech savvy enough to handle compiling stuff. Use the repos I gave you and figure this out on your own with Marlin's official instructions. Don't go on reddit and download premade configs/firmwares, 99% of the time whenever a user "tunes" their printer they've actually just made it worse and they're only confirmation biasing themselves into thinking it's an improvement. Companies like Creality are full of idiots, but the people actually designing these printers are usually themselves printing enthusiasts, see Prusa or Timaz (behind the scenes guy at Creality). I'm not particularly clever but I never had any problems updating my firmware for adding a bltouch to my Ender 3, I'm sure you'll figure it out too.

Why are you printing on a raft? That's 2005-era cope, back when all we had was ABS and extremely warped aluminium beds. Bottoms on rafts are basically always going to be shit, you're printing a mm away from the actual layer of plastic to ensure the result is easily removable, but as you can see the result looks like garbage.

>>2520005
Print at 100% flow rate, and lower your z offset until you get good squish. See pic related. What bed surface are you using? If you can't get it to work with just glass and hair spray, try washing the glass thoroughly with soap and hot water, and try different brands of hair spray. You only need a little, just spray back and forth in a zig zag quickly.
If you absolutely can't get that to work, try painter's tape. Go to a hardware store and buy the widest blue masking tape they have, and just cover the bed in a single layer. Make sure it wraps around behind the glass for a centimetre or so, and then strap the glass down to the bed of the printer with binder clamps. Let the bed cool down to room temperature before you try removing the prints, and each application of tape should last a few prints at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520407
If you have a printer with auto leveling it should be somewhere in the firmware. Google "printer name z offset".
If you have a printer without auto leveling you don't need z offset, just adjust the print bed height with the adjustment wheels, or if you have to, move the z sensor up or down.
If you absolutely must adjust z offset in the slicer, Cura has a plugin to enable this feature. Open market place, find and subscribe the plugin, restart, open settings, scroll down to Build Plate Adhesion, enable Z Offset, close settings, open slicer settings and set z offset to whatever.
The cura option is meant for people who switch between for example PLA and PETG frequently and don't relevel their printers between them. PLA likes to be squished but PETG prefers having a bit of extra distance, so the z offset option exists to let you add 0.1mm offset for your PETG prints. Unless this use case applies to you it's best to just make sure your printer levels properly to begin with rather than add an extra step.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520005
Auto level printers aren't magic. The bed probe eliminates the need to do fine adjustments on the bed level, but it can't do all the work. You still need to level it manually once to start off, so the bed is perpendicular to the gantry of the printer, and you need to adjust z offset because of manufacturing differences in the probe and the hotend.
Make the printer home z and then unlock the x and y motors so you can move it around by hand. Z should remain locked. Adjust z offset until sliding a piece of paper beneath the nozzle meets with a little resistance. Now move the nozzle to each corner of the bed and slide the paper under it. Adjust the wheel below until you feel about the same resistance as you did at the center. Repeat in each corner. Apply a bit of hot glue to each wheel to lock it in place semi-permanently, this way the vibrations of the printer working won't make it uneven. Now start a test print. Compare to >>2520010 and fine tune z offset until your first layer looks perfect. Save to EEPROM.
There, done. From now on auto leveling should handle things on its own. It'll compensate for things like gantry sag on printers with only one z axis rod, or random stresses on the frame slightly twisting it over time. As nozzles wear down over time you'll need to adjust your z offset. Same when you install a fresh nozzle. If you knock the printer around you may need to do a new manual level. If you switch to a new filament or build surface you will probably also need to adjust your z offset. All auto leveling does is remove the tiny intermittent level adjustments you need to do to compensate for vibration and wear.

Generally, 60 to 120% is acceptable. A lower width produces finer detail and a larger width produces better strength. IMO 80% is a good compromise and helps balance strength and detail.

What works FOR ME is I run a 0.5mm nozzle and leave most of my slicer settings as if I was running a 0.4.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520645
Any filament cooled in my nozzle will ooze, PETG worse than PLA I think. And since it's oozing it kind of sticks back and makes a loop on the nozzle. Before auto leveling the nozzle purges and if it's stuck at the end will make a loop. I'll gently disengage then after the purge wait two seconds and whip the purge off.

After the auto level it will pause again and often the nozzle will ooze some more, like a few mm. The few mm is the only thing a skirt needs to then clear and it's usually not looped back. Sometimes I'll pull the ooze bit off too before it starts.

So if you've got a hanging purge or ooze and it doesn't get trapped in the skirt, try adding passes to your skirt or doing a brim. if the skirt brim isn't sticking use gluestick. but I think probably making yoru skirt 3 loops or something will give it more opportunity to dislodge before the print proper starts.

>>2517515
>And there's no particular reason that a "cartridge" can't use a SPI or I2C interface
Oh yeah absolutely. The required external program memory of an RP2040 or ESP8266/ESP32 run on SPI after all. Just if you're trying to use an equivalent 8-bit micro (e.g. an AVR) it's a bit of a hack to get it to load code from external memory for execution, but Mitxela did so and documented the process.
Just if you have parallel memory, you have the option of easily having some fraction of address spaces lead to on-board memory, and some fraction being in the cartridge. Never seen an MCU/MPU with internal program memory that can also read instructions directly from external memory, but I guess some probably exist.

It's called a USB ADC. For a lot of old games though, you can fairly easily reverse engineer the synthesiser (often just a few triangle and square waves and a noise channel) so you can generate it in higher fidelity than the original. Using a logic analyser to record the digital waveforms going into the synthesiser or DAC IC(s) may be required if you can't get at the code.

For something like a pinball machine, depending on vintage, it may use purpose-made analogue synths, for which yeah you'd likely want to just record the voltage waveform. Same for if you can't read the ROM sent to a DAC, but I can't imagine that being the case.

An arduino is a bit slow, you could probably get there with something like an ESP32 and a nice high-quality Texas Instruments ADC IC and an SD card, but altogether it would probably cost more than an equivalent quality USB-audio codec IC, plus take a fair bit of programming effort.

Figured out a faster way to drive a 3-digit decimal display than division on an 8-bit micro that lacks hardware division:
>hundreds H = (N * 41) >> 12
>Hbig = H * 100
>tens T = ((N - Hbig) * 410) >> 12
>Tbig = 10 * T
>ones O = N - Hbig - Tbig
Checked all the values in a spreadsheet, no errors below 1100 or so, which doesn't matter for a 3-digit number.
As per this:
>http://www.avr-asm-tutorial.net/avr_en/calc/HARDMULT.html#mult16by8
The three 16-bit multiplications should only take 10 clock cycles if the compiler knows what's what, less if I can tell it that the result will never be more than 16-bits long. Plus the 12 cycles for Rshifting, or maybe less for 4 Rshifts plus a transposition. As per this:
>https://ww1.microchip.com/downloads/en/AppNotes/doc0936.pdf
A division would take 173 cycles minimum.
It also says that a multiplication routine would take like 105 cycles, but since my AVRs have hardware multiplication I think that doesn't apply, right? Wonder if the compiler simplifies division by a power of 2 into Rshifts too?

For that transposition, basically just grabbing the upper byte of a 16-bit number, does anyone know how I'd do that efficiently in C (e.g. without 8 Rshifts)? Or would those Rshifts just compile down to looking at seperate memory addresses instead? Some guy on the arduino forum suggests that's what happens:
https://forum.arduino.cc/t/changing-a-16bit-binary-number-into-two-8-bit-byte/44940/7
But doing it that way and trusting the compiler is a bit shit IMO. There's gotta be a way of using pointers, right?
