posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518872
>Would raspberry pi have been better?
RasPi is a full computer capable of running Linux and web browsers. It is not a microcontroller. It does have some I/O pins, but the OS mostly gets in the way of using them. And you have to deal with it like a full computer, keeping the OS running, etc.
A microcontroller has nothing but maybe a bootloader. Any OS is built into your project. And there is usually nothing like a file system or network ports.

It's also that much more to throw out when (not if) something gets zapped. I was making a chip reader with a blue pill, and accidentally touched a +12 wire to an I/O pin, and now the thing runs hot because of the blown pin. I knew what I was doing, and was being careful, and still zapped it. I'm kind of surprised that's the only time, there were other times I thought I had, and was wrong. But I started with a bag of twenty for $40 including shipping, seven-ish years ago, and most are still in the bag. And even then, it's only the main chip. I have some lower-spec ST chips that should drop right in.
The main thing you want when playing around with microcontrollers is to have identical spares around. You still want to be careful whenever you hook it up to something, but when it happens you need to be able to pull out another one and get back to work. If you had to change chip type, you would have to fuck with your build configuration. Also it lets you keep more than one project in progress at the same time. Blue pill is about as chink as you can get and still be able to get more.

The thing about micro:bit is that it already has a few useful things on the board (like the LED matrix), so you can do stuff without hooking it up anything, and it has the "better" I/O pins brought out to big holes you can clip to. It can also fit into carrier boards, I got one that was a game-controller style.

>>2517360
6502 was a very simple CPU even for its time. The one difficult bit was that one of the buses was only half the width it needed to be (because pin shortage) and you had to implement some sort of weird latch mechanism to hold half the address and then catch the second half when it came through on the next cycle.

Anyway, I'd recommend picking up the STM32 if you want to learn about embedded systems, or a Raspberry Pi if you want to work more at the software level. I've read that the Pi's instruction set is basically a massively expanded 6502 instruction set. Haven't bothered getting down into machine code on it yet tho.

>>2504840
i'm an arborist by profession.
Even modern high quality chains break from time to time. either from misuse, accident or material fault. on average a chain snaps on me every one to two years. luckily modern chainsaws have a chain catcher under the clutch so even when a chain should snap it will immediately arrest on the catcher as it leaves the bar on the underside and be stopped at the catcher immediately - if you are lucky - just dropping down from the catcher harmlessly or slapping the hand guard on the rear grip where it will lose its momentum.
in the worst of cases one of the chain links will get caught and the rest of the chain will come whipping around on the underside of the bar - miss the hand guard and slap the underside of your rear arm, upper leg or your hip if you are holding the saw sideways.
in any case its going to be like a 35mph whip with teeth but it wont keep running and actually be pulled through your flesh as it hits you. wounds from this should be superficial due to the chain loosing most of its energy on the catch.

should you ever pick up a saw with this safety feature missing or damaged, do not use it!

hey /diy/ this is my cat rupert. I had a question related to a diy topic which is as follows;

does anyone have any experience putting a customised catflip into one of these type of doors? I looked online and i dont want to replace the whole door to get a cat flap model

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2519851
I’ve done it, shit’s easy. You can buy the cat doors at pet stores or online, all you have to do is measure and cut the rectangle out. There’s an overlap of an inch or so to cover up the edges of the cut and make it look clean.

If that were my door, I would measure those two rectangles under the mail flap and try to find a cat door larger than the small rectangle but still fits inside the big one. Or one smaller than the small rectangle would be even better if the cat fits. Or you could go lower, depends how clean you want it to look. To make it flush, for that inch overhang between the opening of the cat door and the frame, you could sand down any ridges on the actual door that prevent it from laying flat.


Get the cat door, trace a line on the door, bust out the jigsaw and cut along the line, and screw in the cat door. 30min or less.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2519851
>>2519856
See, they come as 2 pieces, the outer and inner. So you cut a hole in your door about the size of the opening for the cat door, then the door gets sandwiched between both parts of the cat door. The main thing is trying to make it all look smooth with the existing ridges on the door.

>it didn't fly
>bought some brushless motor and ESC, some carbon fiber sticks, printed v2
>around 600g in total, needed lots of ballast up front, 80cm wingspan
>gave it a test today
>looked like it's going to fly, it even stabilized itself on its own after initial spin to the side, but then motor power just got cut off in half, you could hear it going down in power, and it crashed down
>tested at home, it spins as fast as you want for as long as you want without a propeller, but with the propeller on it goes limp mode after 2-3s of spinning at peak speed and suddenly motor spins very slow

I have very little understanding of how ESCs work, so could someone drop any hints on what could be the possible cause here? It's powered by four 550mah 3.7v 13400 soldered together. Do you think switching to higher-amp 18650 would solve it? I need ballast up front anyway, so I don't think I care much, but I've no idea if it's even going to fix the issue as I'm not sure about the root cause of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2484342
Is there a spec sheet or test data available for your motor? The max draw for your battery cells is 3A or ~45w at 14.8v and it's highly likely that your motor is trying to draw more than that. The 2-3s of max throttle that you get is probably from the ESC's capacitors draining.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2484358
Not much specs, but one i found says
>Max Current (Motor) (A) 35.00
Damn. That means some artificial 100% load at 100% power, right? Or do i actually need 35amp battery pack just to avoid those issues I have?

I've got some quality 18650, and IIRC they were rated 20amp max continuous. If that won't be enough, I guess I'll have to give up and buy one of those lipo packs that all of the cool kids have. For some reason, I never assumed those things can draw so much power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2484372
>That means some artificial 100% load at 100% power, right?
No, it's just the maximum continuous current that the motor can handle thermally. Current draw is proportional to load, if you put an oversize prop on the motor, it's entirely possible to exceed its max current draw and burn it up. What motor do you have and what size is your prop? Just eyeballing it, it looks like you have an undersize prop (or a beefier motor than required to turn it), so you might be able to get away with your 20A 18650 cells although I would strongly recommend just buying a lipo pack since their max current draw is typically so high that it's not even a consideration, you just need to match your motor and ESC.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2484412
>Adding 3 batteries instead of 4 will make it pull more amps, right?
Less volts means for any given RPM/power consumption, you'll require more current draw. However, you'll also have a lower peak RPM at 100% throttle, so your maximum current draw will be lower.
>it's a good learning experience
I'd just try making a 4-cell battery with the 18650 cells, by my estimation they should be able to handle ~80% throttle continuously and maximum throttle in short bursts.

posts.name: Hybrid power train on quadcopter
posts.com: If I attach combustion engine powered generator to quadcopter and let it power four engines, can it increase flight time? Anyone tried it before?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2486808
You can calculate if it'll increase flight time, you just need to know the thermal efficiency of your generator, the energy stored in the fuel, and the weight of the whole system. My guess is that at this scale, the benefit in energy density of combustible fuels isn't going to be enough to offset the weight of an ICE and its poor thermal efficiency, and you'd be better off just putting more battery cells in parallel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2498902
>How easy is it to geolocate encrypted 900MHz
Encryption doesn't matter. Tracking radio signal is as simple as seeing where the transmissions are strongest. If you're not transmitting, they can't find you. And unless you're interfering with an airport, they won't care at all and/or won't have an agent out in time to catch you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2498629

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2498911
>Encryption doesn't matter.
It absolutely does. There are a few communication protocols in use with uavs. The Mavlink protocol is open source. RFD900 radios use Manchester encoding, anyone can decode the binary messages. This would then allow you to identify and read (eg) the GLOBAL_POSITION_INT message which would give you position of the drone in real time.
>radio tracking is as simple as seeing where the transmissions are strongest.
it really isn't. I cant imagine the FAA driving around monitoring signal strength and trying to drive in the direction which makes the number go up. Not an expert but if you had an array of antennae, using either signal strength or time of arrival, doing something like beamforming you would get the direction. You would then need two such arrays to triangulate.

How do we work out how much weight a wing can support to payload capacity? The bottle in pic related is 580g approx and barely any defection. But if the wing is loaded with 580g in the air, it's more evenly already across the wing rather than all right near the tip right?

Eg 1.5kg of load on the wing maybe be more like 200g in that area where the bottle is, with 2 wings it's 3kg, and the body in this model also contributes to lift.

The wing load max is spec'ed 60.6g/dm2 and wing area 19.8dm2 which gives 1.2kg max. Obviously prop, motor, ESC we can change.

But it seems like this could support a lot more? Perhaps a limitation of the control surfaces too then? Though they could be glassed

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2500663
Wing loading isn't about how much force it takes to break a wing, it's about how much weight it can handle in the normal speed envelope before the necessary aspect ratio to maintain level flight starts to stall the airfoil. Also, keep in mind that when you are pulling multiple g's, all your electronics weigh that many times more.

posts.com: Could I combine a drone with waypointing and some image recognition software to automatically count livestock in hilly terrain?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504072
is there actually demand for that? Is it sheep?
You could set up an ardupilot quadcopter with a sony camera, then use opendronemap to make a georeferenced areal map.
After that you would need to produce eg jpeg images of each part of the areal map and use some python package to detect blobs of white of a certain size.
You would need to fly a set height above the terrain (otherwise the blob size would change). This is possible but you would need either a good raster of the terrain or a rangefinder on a gimbal.
It is 100 percent possible to do, just a lot of work, especially if you want an efficient workflow that other people can use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504072
Submarine guy from above signing in.

I thought about doing this before so I started with a simplistic robotic car with a sonar that changes direction if it comes near a solid object, but also strapped a Google Coral TPU board to it with a camera. The ML was designed to recognize people's faces, and then send a signal to the arduino & motor circuit to change direction. The robot (Harry) would then theoretically chase the person around the room. It was laggy (the TPU and arduino do not interface well), and the signals became all confused when the sonar and TPU issued different commands. Probably possible if I went back and put more time into it. Here's Harry (he has a gf robot called Sally). I've stolen the TPU battery and camera off it for other things, and he's dusty af, but he's 98% alive.

Anyway, to relate this to you, you need a TPU like a Coral board and a LOT of images to recognize terrain. People are easy because the libraries are available online... but terrain? I doubt it. If anything, you could download large sections of satellite google maps as the references, then point the camera straight down, and then do image comparisons, then relate it to a long/lat. Don't forget that the TPU, camera require a battery source, and all of this is extra weight. It would be a difficult project.

>>2509921
I'm about 9 months in. Here's a few things that'll help if you haven't heard them yet.
-Be okay with the fact that you'll crash. Everyone does.
-If it's winter where you're at, small branches are practically invisible on analog video. Also your props will explode instead of bend in the cold. Get spares.
-1S batteries will voltage sag pretty bad, especially on a PH2.0 connector. You might change it for GNB27 or BT2.0 at some point.
-Try to keep your batteries at 3.8ish for storage, and don't go under 3.3 resting. Do those and you'll get 6-12 months out of your batteries.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2516372
Haven't played Flowstate, but it looks decent if you can run it. I'd try Liftoff first though, it's pretty much the standard.
As for your little drone, set up a switch to go from rate mode to angle mode, so you can switch to self stabilization if you get in trouble while fucking around in acro mode, or at least start off in angle mode for a while to develop some muscle memory of what stick does what, and can get a feel for the throttle. Quads are very dependant on actively flying the throttle, so learn to feather it in quick little blips to maintain the trajectory you are trying to fly. Also, like snowboarding, flying an FPV drone is easier with a bit of momentum to carve with, when you start out you don't really know what you want to do in the air so it's easy to default to trying to hover to gather your thoughts. Hovering actually takes a fair amount of skill though, you'll learn it, but for now just set your camera angle pretty low, and pitch the quad forward until the horizon is level in the middle of the screen, and just fly it around like an airplane.
This is all somewhat frustrating when you start out, but stick with it and you will continually amaze yourself with the new things you learn to do.

With an SDR you can make your own "cell tower" and nearby phones will connect to it, as it will have the strongest signal. This is how the Stingray (google it) works. If you don't have it pass on traffic, then it will essentially just cause all the connected phones to have no service.

Just target 3rd Order IM Frequencies in your area f1 + (f1 - f2) and you will give everyone heart ache

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521460
I'll Elaborate
lets use b12 as an example
you have a downlink carrier frequency between 728(f2)Mhz and 746(f1)Mhz
is the (IM3) is 764 Mhz and 706 Mhz
since devices have to be listening to that whole swath, the difference between f1 and f2 creates noise in IM3
best part is that its "natural" unlike "overpowering" a carrier frequency like traditional jammers since you are just introducing noise to impact the QoS and even >100 dBc can ruin service handling to the point that not even calls can be placed.

So currently the AC on top of my house is about to finally kick the bucket, been working for well over a decade so it's really whatever, but after seeing people shoot shit about it online I am curious about installing a mini split system in a home already setup for central air

It's a single story 1300ish sqft 3 bedroom house and no one hardly utilizes the living room unless family comes over it's just three people living in the house on in the back two bedrooms as an office/bedroom setup where there is a door they built in the hallway, the other lives in the third bedroom and the last one lives in the garage in a pseudo studio and they use a window ac/heater combo stuck in the wall

So I am wondering is it better to get a new unit for the roof since the house is already setup for central air or is buying a mini split system a decent way to go for a house like that installing one in the living room and then one more in each room, I hear they are much more efficient power wise since you can have the less use areas off most of the time, or we could just go full ghetto and put cheap window units in each section of the house and use as needed with portable heaters as well, we don't live in the most amazing neighborhood so we don't care about being a little ghetto

Do anons have any experience with this and could provide a little insight?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521375

In your position, I'd replace the central unit. The majority of the draw of a mini split is that you don't need the ductwork. You already have it. If you want, you can get electronic baffles ("zone dampers") that cut off air to areas you aren't using.

>the AC on top of my house is about to finally kick the bucket

How? Central systems are inherently modular. You don't really ever have to replace the whole thing, barring upgrading the entire system to something more efficient.

posts.com:
interesting...
well trying to replicate ur setup mentally doesn't make a lot of sense.
unless the circuit was wired like in my pic

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520897
>>2520866
so here is the explanation:
first of all voltmeters are essentially ammeters with a resistance in series with them.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltmeter
understanding that will allow us to understand the circuit behavior.
starting with circuit A like in my pic:
current flows from the voltage source into the resistor and voltmeter to the cap and back to the source.
the current flow is in the same direction in the voltmeter and the resister hence the positive voltage.
as the capacitor charges the voltage across it increases, and thus the current across the resistor and voltmeter decrease until it stops completely when the cap fully charges, the potential difference across the resistor and voltmeter is zero at steady state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520900
>>2520897
>>2520866
for circuit B a similar things happen but with a tiny trick, the voltmeter is a significant current path...
assuming the current flows from the the source to the resistor this creates a potential across the cap as current flows, simultaneously current is flowing in the voltmeter however it is in the opposite direction to the resistor hence the negative voltage.
as the voltage across the cap equals zero, the current across the voltmeter will equal zero, and thus the voltage across the voltmeter will be zero at steady state.

mentally this makes sense, but considering ur component values u wouldn't have been able to measure it with a cheap of the shelf multimeter, since for circuit A it would take 0.1 ms and for circuit B 0.1s to reach zero...
idk it just seems unlikely that u have actually have seen these observations since most of the shelf meters' refresh rate is 180Hz at best, and screen refresh rates rarely exceed 2-4Hz...
just seems a bit fishy yk....

posts.com:
Hire an inspector first, get a proper run down on what needs to be done. Start at the foundations, are they sound? Are the ground drains working properly? Do you have asbestos anywhere in the home? Is there mold? Is there dry rot? etc.

Drywall I did myself and paid a guy to mud it. That's about the extent someone with zero experience should be able to do.

>>2519288
Honest answer - if you're not living in it, as long as you have time/money, you could get it done. But it's realistically a tear-down. You're basically rebuilding the house at this point, I guarantee that it needs all new plumbing, wiring, septic, etc. So you're replacing everything. How much is too much, for your budget? When/if do you plan to live in it? What's the neighborhood like, for potential rental income?
I mean, with some study and going slowly, you might get some of it done. You want professionals dealing with the roof, and electrical/plumbing.
This has every red flag for being a complete money pit. To what end? What is your final plan for the house? What is your realistic potential here?
If you plan to live in it, that's one thing. But if you want to fix it up to flip it, you could put a bunch of money into it, but won't be able to sell it for what it's now worth, if prices are lower in that area.
Your time, your money. Could be a big toilet you flush a big chunk of your paycheck into every month, for little or no return.

Like another anon said, get an inspector in there. Go over every inch of the house. Then get estimates from electricians, plumbers, and hvac for what they consider to be legal/recommended upgrades, while you get the shell of the house repaired. Maybe call around local contractors and see if they'd be willing to consult and just sit down and write you out a general plan, and throw them some of the work, like the roof.
Get the foundation checked first, like other anons have said. If that's fucked, you're fucked.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477882
Induction doesn't require material to be magnetic, just conductive. Energy transfer is more efficient when magnetic, but steel will become non-magnetic when sufficiently heated. If anything you would prefer a non-magnetic, non conductive crucible such that the metal is directly heated rather than indirectly through walls of crucible. Big challenge in getting up to temperature is all of the heat losses due to radiation and convection. For cast iron / cast steel graphite-based crucibles are most commonly used. Not straight graphite but don't know the exact formulation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477882

Oh, it's you. You need to learn thermodynamics. The steel furnaces are lined with ceramic liners (usually some cementatious clay). This + the steel's ability to be cooled by air is enough to avoid melting.

Whe the clay liner fails you get all the molten metal shooting out the hole in the now-melted steel.

The lid and liner are very thick relqtovely speaking; this insulates the melt inside.

Do you mean Silicon Carbide? If so, that's fine to use with Induction furnaces. any ferrous can eat the Silicon carbide over time and you won't have great composition control in a "small batch" furnace, but it might not matter. they use them for cast iron charges in some batch shops.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2488793
Most of the iridium on Earth (probably) ended up bonded to iron and is still molten beneath the crust, which is the reason there is so little accessible to us.
We do mine it, it does occur naturally, it's just rare stuff.
There's more of it in meteorites than in the layers of Earth we have access to, that's not unusual, that's true of numerous elements.
This makes it useful as one of the indicators of large meteorite impacts, one of many valid and observed indicators.
That's about it. It's useful stuff, been produced and used commercially for just shy of 200 years now.
It's just uncommon in the top layers of the Earth's crust where we can access it.

In the scale of the universe, it's an element with a fairly high atomic number (77), so it's going to be relatively uncommon compared to "most" elements with lower atomic numbers. This isn't a perfect rule, but it's a decent rule of thumb.
The reasons why are complex, you'd be wanting to read up on cosmic nucleosynthesis to get an idea of how various elements were formed by the Big Bang, exploding stars, merging stars, cosmic rays, all kinds of neat stuff. Isotopes and stability play a big role in this, certain elements don't have known stable isotopes, and are so "unlikely" to exist in nature they may well not exist anywhere in the universe they aren't actively being produced by an intelligence with the intention of producing them, like we do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2490205

The most viable iridium deposits on Earth are massive, fuck-off huge ancient impact craters from around the time the crust was forming an stabilizing. those are actually a big part of the reason Africa has so much mineral wealth in general. Outside of that, you find a some in old volcanic complexes that have eroded away.

You can pull "native" iridium from copper and platinum refining in minuscule amounts, or in very rare igneous deposits as microscopic bare nuggets alloyed with other metals. There's a couple iron-iridium minerals and one copper-iridium mineral that forms naturally as inclusions in deposits of other platinum and iron-group minerals, but they're vanishingly small - 5 - 10 micron in diameter, and very very sparse.

Basically, the tiny amount that we currently produce is all produced "accidentally" as a byproduct of refining other rare metals. most of the viable sources occur as a "side product" of mining gold conglomerates in Africa and gold sands in North America.

it's a damn shame, as iridium complexes might end up being some of the most compelling phosphors and catalysts ever discovered, but no one in their right mind is ever going to suggest large scale industrialization of an iridium-based chemistry. Even metallurgical uses are basically all luxury items at this point, with some very low volume extreme-condition industrial uses.

>>2496976
The power requirements are MASSIVE. Always used for small batch metallurgy or low melting temp metals that need VERY carefully controlled temperature profiles. Large batch Induction heaters are almost always used as reheaters or preheaters these days. Arc heating or gas fired is still preferred.

Induction smelters are great for fine control and quick batching but are more expensive than any other heat source.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2499296
Heat red hot. Oil quench with pliers no swishing (firing tip down). Heat at AT LEAST 500°F (more like 600 if you can) until it shows a good darkening yellow color.

That should give you a proper hardened profile with enough tempering to not explode.

Google search (O1 tool steel tempering graph) and aim for 50-55HRC if you want more info.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508422
Easy recipe: take some generic 1020 or 4140 or something (a proper quenchable tool steel if you are brave) and cut it into small chunks (or buy some steel shot if lazy). Take some cast iron powder. Pack the chunks VERY WELL and tightly into a crucible and seal it or at least borax the shit out of the top. Bring to half way between the melting temperature of the cast iron and of the steel.

The cast iron melts and diffuses into the steel. Eventually the chemistry of the steel and castiron average out until it is a mass of solid chunks and intermingled semi-solid mushy not-quite-cast iron. Consistency of a concrete that is a little too dry. You need to only heat it long enough to get this diffusion about half way - if it becomes 100% solid you went too long. Allow this to slowly cool so that everything diffuses well together but maintains a distinct pattern.

The steel you used is mostly the original steel (now higher carbon) but is all bound with a web of very carbidic pearlite, carbides, and other high-Si intermetallics.

I really like the pale blue color you get when tempering steel to spring steel temps. However, I'm not too keen on the appearance you get when using differential tempering. Plus, it's more difficult than an even temper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2512956
That's hot enough to restore flexibility and close internal cracks. It will lose hardness if it IS a tempered steel but will be the hardest it can be outside of requenching and tempering.

>>2513066
Anything that is carbide forming (tool steels, bearing steels) resists carbon diffusion through martensite (huge Ni/Cr atoms + small Mn/V atoms fug up the diffusion) so you can develop a decorative oxide layer but maintain strength and hardness.

Look for "impact grade" tool steels if you're making a sword.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2516112
Acid reacts with and rapidly corrodes the surface of metal. Can be used in combination with a resist to make some sort of pattern or just applied generally to expose virgin metal, as for weld testing.
You can get both sulfuric and hydrochloric acid from a well stocked hardware store. Sulfuric is sold as drain cleaner, and HCL is sold for cleaning concrete and masonry labeled as muriatic acid. Even the acetic acid in cleaning vinegar will work, albeit more slowly. Copper sulfate, which is sold for horticulture and aquaculture can also be used for etching, but I'm not sure of the specifics of the process.
Don't hurt yourself

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518598
With PLA I've had the best luck turning the mold upside down and melting at 400C. Then turn up to 450C which will cause anything left to burn out. The kitchen oven won't quiet do it, so I made my own out of a stovetop heating element, inswool, PID, and a washing machine drum. I found a 3D printing filament "Mold-Lay" that is low temp enough to be melted out in the kitchen oven, but still makes a smoky mess and more expensive than PLA. I usually use 50% sand 50% plaster. The 45 minute plaster works better than the 15 minute plaster (and is cheaper too). Use a paint brush to paint the mixture on the surface before fully submerging to make sure it fills all the nooks and crannies. Using 356 aluminum rather than potluck aluminum will give much better results (found someone on Ebay selling for $3/lb).

I'm not entirely sure what the case is in America, but here in the EU wago or similar style claps are the only types of splices approved for new installations, the old screw caps tended to oxidize while solder would eventually separate from the wire, in both cases you'd end up with an increased resistance which in turn would lead to unnecessary heat development and the possibility of a house fire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you are holding there is the cladding from an uranium fuel rod, most likely a souvenir from a decommissioned nuclear reactor. They are usually encased in a shielded container and only taken out for educational purposes, with appropriate protection, as they can still be quite "hot" for decades after removal.

Uranium is twice as dense a lead, that's why it is so incredibly heavy.

For proof, here's me holding one that has been decontaminated and is well intact.

Yours appears to be slightly darker in color and shows a significant amount of wear, which indicates that the chromium coating (the shiny finish) has started to erode over time.

This is not good, and you really do not want to hold that with your bare hands.


Are there any markings on it??

>>2517441
See that conchoidal fracture? That, my good sir, is probably elemental silicon. Probably a wafer-stock rod from a chip-manufacturing plant.
It's easy enough to test: Silicon is a semiconductor, so if you have a multimeter lying around your abode, set it on ohms and take a resistance reading between two close points on the surface. You should get a moderate resistance instead of nearly zero as you would expect for an actual metal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519695
I don't believe you will get a satisfactory result by coating the entire device in luminescent material. The substance would be radiating light over top of the printed surfaces. This is a much different effect than shining a light on a reflective surface. It would be more akin to the glare of light on a monitor, where-in the monitor is trying to emit light, but the surface of the screen is reflecting light in front of the monitor's light. It would wash out the printed letters on the keyboard and make them unreadable.
Perhaps that is okay, if you are a touch-typist and not trying to read the keyboard. But if that were the case, why would you be asking for a lighting solution? The keyboard appears to already have the usual tactile markers for hand placement.
But I think you'd get a much better effect by just detail painting in the accents you need lighted, like the printed letters on each key.

Furthermore, luminescent materials are not "free energy." They do require something to power them.
Some do retain the charge imparted by exposure to UV light and release it gradually after being removed, but the effect of relying on the very limited energy capacity of the coating will likely be underwhelming.
There are radio-luminescent materials like tritium paint. You will pay accordingly for the quality, but these do last several years.
But, ultimately the most DIY feasible solution is just to apply phosphorescent paint that reacts to UV light, and then use a UV light to illuminate it. You will obviously need to power the UV light source, but this is not a difficult DIY problem to solve. You could just put a headlamp on for the purpose.

Actually, why NOT just wear a fucking headlamp, perhaps with a red filter to be less offensive in the dark? Better than fucking about with paint and shit.

>>2516968
Time out timer (ToT) is an option that can be modified or disabled in most handhelds but they are not made for continuous txmit nor the rules allow for it. You will probably bust the ppt button or even burn the txmitter given enough battery or direct power source.
If you want to try on a cheap disposable device anyway I suggest replacing the internal push ppt button with a switch and use a low tx power.
If your intention is that to emit a beacon signal you can make use of the VOX function instead with a direct cable connection to the sound source played in a loop. It will txmit automatically but only when sound is played, leaving the freq free when not.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2518417
The entire point of ham radio is to experiment, test, and improve. Building radios, amps, antennas, etc. It's a hobby built around doing shit yourself. One of the coolest things you can do is pick up a basic diy radio kit to build and solder yourself. Then find an old lamp or any electrical wiring you have laying around and build a 5ft dipole. Don't worry about a balun, you're just receiving anyway. Run it straight to the radio with some wire and right out your window. 2.5ft on each side, have them hanging against the wall or something it literally does not fucking matter. The antenna could be a 15in long rusty nail from your backyard, fm broadcasts are so strong you'll probably pick shit up.

Look up qrp stations and how well they work with ft8 transmissions. Every satellite in space could be nuked right now, we'd still have world-wide radio wave communications to some degree. Our fundamental understanding of radio waves and data transmissions far exceeds most people's expectations. Building a basic transceiver on any band is something a child can do with an instruction manual and 0 experience.

posts.com:

Also, you don't necessarily need a battery either. A simple wind or hydroelectric generator, even a pathetically small one, could power something like this enough to receive.

>>2518417
Honestly, the hardest bit about building radios is conforming to a bunch or rules that make sure you don't piss everybody else off.

You can build a fairly powerful spark-gap morse code transmitter that you can hear all around the world on practically all frequencies form nothing but copper wire, and some iron. Hell you can pick up the transmissions with just some wire, a pencil and a razor.

That's in fact how the first radios communications where realized. The first recover used a vile with some iron shavings as a pseudo-diode.

However, if I where to to that today, everybody ant their grandmothers dog would be backing down my neck for disrupting communications.

It really depends on how much resources you have available.
If you can scramble up any form of transistors, you can build decent transmitters and receivers from shit you find around, with nothing but some math.

Capacitors can be build from aluminum foil and baking sheets, resistors are still just really thin copper wire around a ceramic core. Semiconductors get a little tricky to diy. Pure semiconductor grade shit isn't found in everyday life.
Diodes can be improvised from pencil leads and oxidized iron. GI-s used to build foxhole radios using razors and copper wire. The wire would serve as a tuning coil, while the razor-pencil combo worked well enough as a diode to pick up AM broadcasts.

Given enough time, resources and motivation I'm reasonably convinced some autist could DIY workable vacuum tubes from relatively common items. After that you're pretty much working with near enough modern electronics

Yea, that's the first thing that came to my mind. That's the carrot of the General license
There are weekend contests and an online log to track and confirm who many of the 340 'countries' you've worked.
>HT's with FM repeaters
Depending on your location, that's a beautiful network of helpful old men which is a very untapped resource when it comes to day to day help. Need directions? New in town and want restaurant recommendations? Car broke down and you don't have a cell phone?
Then there are technical hobbies with learning and building antennas or assembling kits or tracking balloons with APRS.
You can send text messages and emails too now without a cellphone or internet. It's so empowering and most if not all of the services are free.
>i didn't realize the depth of it
It's very deep and also disjointed. If you're in the Ohio/Indiana/Kentucky area, there's a podcast called AB4WS that gives a weekly update on what's coming up.

You can literally get on the air right now.
Call a nice and slow CQ, at the speed you're comfortable receiving at.. Bunch of beginners will be hogging to talk to anyone and everyone.
If somebody contacts you that's too fast ask for QRS PSE.
Just send out 599 for a few days.
Then learn full boomer QSO-s. Even if you cant get the full QSO just catch the callsign and RST. Nothing else really matters.

posts.name: Anonymous

>ugh. They really are 2 separate skills.
That is the painful truth.
Beginner mistake 1: fire off a message at best speed, then get a reply at same speed, which turns out to be way too fast, ending up begging with a QRS.

Beginner mistake 2: optimistically fire off a QRQ and forgetting to specify speed, discover the other party is capable of speeds in excess of what was thought humanely possible, and once again having to submit a QRS.

Makita, Milwaukee, Dewalt, and Flex are contractor grade tools. They will all exceed your needs and you will not use them often enough for the differences between them too matter. Save your money and buy mid tier tools.

Ryobi if you have a Home Depot near you or Kobalt if you have a Lowes. When it comes to misc tools you don't use often buy corded.

Drills, Impacts, Recips, Circular saws, and oscillating saws should be cordless. Don't fall for the wormdrive circular saw meme, you don't need that much power. Mitre saws, palm sanders, angle grinders and other tools you probably aren't using outside of your shop/garage don't need to be cordless.

posts.com:
>>2521062
Basically wood garage construction then. Rockwool on the walls. Spacing isn't standard & the studs aren't deep enough so you'll have to add wood to do it right.

Ceiling first though. Spray foam is best but a few sheets of foil-coated foamboard, 1.5 or 2" will make a huge difference. Cut & press in place, right up against the underside, tape any seams & spray-foam the perimeter if there are gaps. Get stuff that can be left exposed if you want to meet code - unfoiled foam board usually has to be covered with something.

Amateur here, but did my (ancient) garage that way. As long as the roof doesn't leak you're good.

>>2520673
Problem with running a tube up is that it only gives you high pressure if you're not drawing any water out of it. As soon as you open the valve the tube will empty out and the pressure will rapidly drop until you've just got a tank's worth of pressure again. The way to get continuous high pressure out of the system would be to move the entire tank to the top of the hill.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520686
>But I just took a look at the water heater and it says max head 25ft fuck
The friction of the line itself will reduce the head pressure. You may not need to do anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520752
Friction losses only happen when there's water flowing through the system. If the flow stops downstream of the tank then your system becomes deadlocked and you reach hydrostatic pressure.

posts.name: Anonymous

You want to draw the air that the fire consumes and sends up the chimney from an exterior source. If it draws from inside the house then the windows/doors will have to leak in cold air to replace the air that is consumed for the combustion of the fire.

Ideally you want your buildings to have positive pressure so that the windows and doors will leak out air instead of leaking in air.

>>2518885
It was the combination of a few factors, but the biggest one is called "dot gain". Colors are made by mixing size and location of dots in 4 different colors. Sort of like how digital screens mix RGB pixels together to create colors.

When you print those dots, there are factors that can make the dots larger or smaller than intended. In this case the paper it was printed on absorbed the ink more, creating larger dots. There might have been other factors, I don't know.

The ad was already very dark and moody looking to begin with. I did one quick pre-press at a local printer, and it came out dark... I had them lighten it a bit and due to time/money had to send the files right away.

I was really proud of the ad. It was my first "big" print ad, and I also handled the photography and design from top to bottom. Like, I was planning on framing a copy of it lol.

Power supplies are not the place to start learning about electronics. I've been doing electronic repair semi-professionally for a decade and I still avoid opening one of those fucking things if I can avoid it. >>2517594
>>2517691
OP as this anon said >>2517691 , I wouldn't go for PSUs as my first repair, but if u have the guts and the brains why not...
so here are the 3 golden roles of PSU repair:

1. never under any circumstance work on it live or connected to the power cable!!! keep the board outside the unit completely unconnected to anything while working on it!!

2. always double check the safety off the board, especially if recently powered or if it is connected to high value capacitors that operate at moderate to high voltage (100v-2kv+), these can pack a strong punch sometimes enough to vaporize a man!!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=coW1RHUsf_I

so make sure they are discharged b4 u even think of working on the board!!

3.look at the board carefully, give the board a smell check and if u notice a burned smell or see a component that looks charred or cracked or burned or blown then replace it.
check for common culprits, like switching transistors and diodes, tantalum caps, electrolytic caps, thyristors, Opto-isolators and the such like since they tend to fail first and be the most stressed in operation (here i assume yk how to test them).

once u did that u can start actually repairing and diagnosing the board, i prefer to look at the mains side first, since it tends to be the simplest to diagnose, check the x and y class caps, movs and ptcs, working ur way down stream...
I am the OP from the fixinga thread, i really love seeing anons trying to fix instead of endlessly consuming, just follow the golden roles and don't kill ursellf!!!

posts.name: fixinga OP here
posts.com:
>>2517775
nice job anon, make sure u get the same type of cap and ratings...


>>2517799
for de-soldering, I would highly recommend using a solder sucker/pump like a goot GS-108 or TP-100 which will generally work much faster and stress the pads less from my experience especially for someone who never used solder wick b4.
also might want to watch these first before u start if u haven't soldered b4:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL926EC0F1F93C1837

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBXXuFXCtmtqlamIEfu3lSTzM5t1k2cx_

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0wI-5YZQm4

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpgMn88Qfjs

follow the steps and complete the primary check/repair, then you should go for a secondary diagnoses, which has 3 golden roles:

1. during this stage u will have to power up the board, the best way to power it is an isolation transformer, so the board is kept floating (galvanically isolated) this will reduce the risk of electrocution, also install a fast acting low current breaker or an incandescent lightbulb/heater or a fuse inline for added safety against short circuits accidental and otherwise, i personally use a 200w ceramic heater it if it glows i know there is a short and due to the PTC nature of the heater it limits the current enough to not cause catastrophic failure...
u could work on it on that state, but still i wouldn't recommend that for a beginner, so wear gloves and boots while working, and if u don't have access to an isolation transformer u have to use a GFCI/RDC outlet or breaker in line with circuit u are powering:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=olq9wdeNS4c

2.make sure yk where ur hands are!! keep ur hands off the board and the board always powered down at all times except during the test!!!


3. thou shalt check voltages, start from the primary side, since the voltages there are known for the most part, if they are in the ball park (+10v or -10v) its ok, any thing higher u should investigate the primary components

Also alot of quality clothing creation ie tailoring is less about sewing per se and more about understanding fitting, anatomy, and pattern making/ modification and related things like the technical qualities and selection of fabrics and their orientation.

Being realistic about not just your skills but the equipment you have at your disposal is the key to getting good results...pic very much related.

posts.name: Anonymous

Oh lawdy
You thought you could post some long-ass replies... without getting long-ass replies??

(Up front: I used to work in a Honda seat plant, then a Toyota main assembly plant... Now I just have a side business.)

There's definitely a gulf. A home sewer gets used to seeing needles 5/per in one of those little plastic flip cases. In a shop, the smallest box is 100/per... and you get flats of boxes.

>never think you can just sew through it
Nah, sometimes you can sew through it.
Part of "getting good" is knowing your machine's limits. For an industrial machine, the needle is the thing that's going to break. (No plastic gears, etc.) The worst you'll do is trip the safety clutch.

Sewing through one of those complimentary yard sticks is a trick for customers. Lowe's would call it 'whitewood', but it's the least-dense wood known to man. Punch a needle through it, and their eyes pop out. "Y(ou put your fingers right next to THAT thing??"

You're missing the trick: business license, buy from wholesalers, deduct your 'expenses'.
Even if you only make a few things a year, this can work out in your favor. From there it's a slippery slope... hey, just open up your own shop... you already have a machine, a layout table, etc.

>sewing something custom (boat upholstery, etc.)
I'm a humble person, but absolutely you can have a small repair business on the side. This is just >50% my income.... and it's my "side job".

I do lots of heavy equipment repairs, and side-by-sides (lots), motorcycles, etc. There's a gravel yard near me, and those fat boys wear out the seats on the big Volvo loaders like clockwork. Same thing for oil/gas field trucks. Boats are a seasonal thsing. Easy money (as in, 'simple patterns'), but you have to pay for primo materials.

Sometimes I even help out a 'rival shop', because he has a contract with the local BOE to redo school bus seats. His work comes in waves... "can you redo 1040 bus seats??".
The patterning etc, is dead simple, but it's one of those things where you just have to put in the hours. Can't shortcut it, can't outsource it. Having three people (him, his wife, myself) on machines does it in a reasonable time frame. And 'keeping the contract' is worth it for everyone involved.

Then there's people who had 'just' the side impact air bag go off, and want a quick repair, etc...

Ha, if you're into Jap grannies weaving stuff, there's no shortage on Youtube.

As an entry point, look up "Jap nail weaving", "tsuzure ori".

>lay down a consistent stitch without a guide
We used to use machinist rules that were 0.5mm thick. Not a common fraction, but 1/48" is close. You can imagine it, a strip of spring steel, guiding that with your fingers, mellowing out the pressure points. And it just happens to have measurements on it. A long enough straight edge, wide enough to press on any single seam, etc. Very handy.

>>2482219
There definitely is some specialized software I’ve seen people use but I forget the name of it. There is even some fancy specialty software— when I was working in automotive, one of the prototype lab guys was showing me this software that converted 3D CAD (in my case, of a seat design), to 2D patterns. It required very precise inputs for material parameters— IE it would even predict how the leather/vinyl/cloth would stretch and wrinkle. At the end of the day though they still had to modify it and troubleshoot it by hand to get it perfect.

In my experience, CAD is only useful for saving old designs. Using a pattern consisting of multiple pieces of printer paper taped together is super annoying. I used to make my patterns on heavy cardstock 36” x 24” drawing paper but now I use a thin-gauge plastic. You want something that you can actually trace around. For the most part, I make one-off pieces and won’t use a pattern at all but just measure and cut the fabric directly. Get a ceramic pencil or leather pen so you can draw on fabric directly and then wipe away all marks later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2482805
not sure what you mean by prototyping tbqh, the automotive industry is so massive in scope that it happens in so many places simultaneously

There are:
>OEM prototyping labs
Been in Ford’s prototype labs where they hand craft seats wayy before the designs ever get passed to engineers— seems badass to work in one of these and there is a lot of one/off projects they work on. Artisan-type job.
>Tier 1 prototyping labs
Essentially a similar function except these companies are putting together nice samples of their capabilities— Ford/GM/stellantis execs review them while deciding who to source a program to. Artisan-type job.
>Tier 1 & 2 development
Once the business has actually been sourced, these people are turning an idea/design into a manufacturable product. Engineering type job.
>Tier 1 & 2 launch team/quality team
Navigating how to put together the product in the lowest cost manner. Evaluating engineering changes for downstream effects. Seeing what happens when you sub the 12 $0.60 clips in the seat for 8 $0.30 clips. Engineering type job— this is where I was. From an actual sewing perspective, kinda lame.
>Tier 1 & 2 manufacturing team
Doing trials and evaluations as the design preps to go into production. In cut & sew, all of these people are generally going to be in Mexico. Operator/MFG type job.

I always thought it would be cool to work at one of the prototyping companies in Detroit or the OEM prototype labs. In general though, automotive is so massive that you are just a cog in the machine and few people have the ability to both effect design AND to actually carry it out. To change a small thing on a seat requires paperwork to move through several teams. I work in aerospace now which is its own beast but ultimately it feels like less cooks in the kitchen which I like.

posts.com:
>>2469395
>how did you learn to sew?
I dislike it when things get thrown out that don't need to be thrown out as a matter of principle. One day something I liked (it was a pocket in my jacket I think) had a hole, and I didn't want it to have a hole, so I fixed it with the most atrocious hand sewing job you can imagine. Felt good about it, within a week it reopened, so I bought a hand sewing kit, watched some tutorials, fixed it properly that time, and since then I fix minor issues on textiles by hand.
I also have a memory of me sewing once as a kid, I was in my early teens I think, and we used to meet up as friends in a park and grill together as a sort of summer picnic. Everyone had a backpack, one person brought the coal, one person the grill, one person cuttlery and dishes, etc. I wanted to make a leather case for the cutlery to put into, so I planned it and bought leather, only to realize that handsewing leather is not that easy. My mother saw me struggle and together we finished handsewing it. Nice memories.
A year ago I lost a lot of weight and as a result my clothes didn't fit me anymore. I tried tailoring by hand, but it all looked like ass. When my grandmother died and we sold her stuff, I got her sewing machine, so since then I do minor fitting of clothes on it when I just bought them. Pretty fun. I should probably put more effort in learning more though.
>any advice to beginners?
Get a basic sewing kit, it's cheap as fuck. Different colors of thread, different needles, one or two thimbles and one of those wire tools to help thread the thread through the needle and you can get started.
A running stitch, backstitch and ladder stitch are enough for basic fixing of most textiles, and take a total of 5-10 minutes to learn.
Apart from that, just get started.

What does selvedge mean as opposed to a double stitch? You mean having a little strip protecting all of your seams? I made a skirt for my girlfriend that was single stitch. Is it going to fall apart one day and embarrass her?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2497772
He's talking about sewing the edge of the fabric. But his terms are a bit mixed up, and there is a typo. "Served" should be "serged". And fabric with selvage, as long as that's intact, doesn't need any extra treatment--it won't unravel.

To see selvage, look at the long seam in your jeans on the inside, pretty common to have a red thread in there as decoration. To see a serged seam, look at the armpit on a tshirt. The machine that makes that seam has a cutting knife to trim/tidy the edge of the fabric, and it wraps the thread around the outer edge (to keep it from unravelling), and the resulting stich has some flexibility (will stretch with the fabric vs busting).

>having a little strip protecting all of your seams
That's pretty common with home-sewn garments, having a strip of 'bias tape' to protect a seam. Some machines also have programmed stitches (overedge, overlock, double overlock, etc) that are sort of cheater versions of what a serger produces.

>made a skirt for my girlfriend that was single stitch. Is it going to fall apart
But it's impossible to tell without seeing your seam. 'Single stitch' can mean a lot of things, from the most basic straight line to a bar tack.

posts.com:
>>2505531
>singer 201
Yeah, that's a very good all-rounder, and built to last. Look it up on ISMACS, I'm sure they'll have a manual.
Sewing on a classic machine is a treat. For something so old and heavy, you'll be surprised how quiet, and how smooth the action is. And full rotary hook machines lay down very consistent stitches. And overall, it's easy to find parts for Singer machines.
If it doesn't have reverse, don't worry about it. There are a few (not backstitch) techniques for locking your stitches. Pretty recently Alexander Dyer had a Youtube video overview, like 5 minutes. (One technique he didn't mention: you can flip the stitch length lever to ~0 or 0, and just 'sew in place' for a few stitches, and it will lock that end).

>heavier stuff
One thing people often overlook is that these old straight stitch machines are good with lightweight materials. A lot of it is because the hole in the needle plate is so small, so the fabric can't get drawn down towards the bobbin.

the edges of your jacket are all sewn together. There are military gore-tex jackets that have loop for patches sewn on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2505792
>the edges of your jacket are all sewn together
Yes, but then there's a strip of "seam sealing tape" applied over the stitches, to cover the stitch holes. Looks like this pic.

>>2505657
>afraid that sewing would screw up the goretex membrane
It will. Even if you use the smallest possible needle, and non-wicking thread, water will still get in. Those membranes only function when they're contiguous.

>old windbreaker jacket (100% polyester)
There's different kinds of Goretex. Most is 3 layer (outer fabric, goretex middle, liner fabric), some is 2 layer (outer, goretex, no liner). Are you saying your jacket has a polyester shell, or liner?
Anyway, I would recommend sewing the loop to your jacket, and then seam taping.
If you're doing a line on the back panel, that would be easy. Something like an arm patch/armband would be much more fiddly (I'm thinking about reflective elements on something like a cycling jacket).

Most tapes are heat-sensitive, Melco is a common brand. It's kind of a pain to iron the stuff on, because it's so easy to melt synthetic fabrics while you're setting the tape. The proper tool for it is a tiny iron, they look more like soldering irons (look up "electric leather iron", and Clover makes one too). If you use a normal household iron, you'll only be using the inch or half inch at the very tip, and it's more work to maneuver. It wouldn't be too bad on a broad, flat piece of fabric though.

I'd recommend the pressure-sensitive kind if you can find some. Usually they are marketed as material specific (tape for X fabric, tape for Y fabric). Just make sure the fabric is clean, and press it on with a thumb/felt pad. RBTR sells a "dyneema repair tape" that sticks quite well to other fabrics too. I've had strips stuck to the polyester liner of some Xpac since 2018, no peeling, no leaks.

DIY coming in clutch, good info guys. After some research I found genuine truth in these statements. Skids/wood marked MB contain Methyl Bromide.
>Methyl bromide is a fumigant used to control pests in agriculture and shipping. Methyl bromide also depletes the ozone layer. Therefore, along with other countries, the United States has phased out production and consumption of methyl bromide with important exceptions for critical uses as well as quarantine and pre-shipment.
https://www.epa.gov/ods-phaseout/methyl-bromide
I pick up this wood from some kind of manufacturing/assembly location. Most crates are marked Westinghouse Motor Co.(China) or something.
Thanks to some, I can now identify wood that is safe salvage VS wood that might give you cancers to salvage. I hope this information can be used by future generations as I have been sanding and cutting these MB boards for a couple months now.

>>2492083
bout tree fiddy

on a more serious note, your geometry is fucked for subtractive manufacturing. you would need to run that through *at least* a VMC, turning center, and maybe even a key seater. you might be able to expedite it a little bit by using a turn-mill to face, turn to OD, drill/bore, drill extraneous holes, then cut off. then you'd have to find a way to mill out/broach those "teeth" on the OD. a turn-mill would be very, very hard pressed to do that but i don't program turn mills so i can't say for sure.

the center is fine, the holes are fine, what's fucking you up are the teeth (and more specifically the cut and fillet that needs to be applied in between). that's the kind of thing that's hard to accurately mill out.

lastly, what are the tolerances involved here? if you're running +/-.025" on this, that's a whole hell of a lot easier than +/-.005". any GDT involved? how about post process after it's cut? for a part like that, you're looking at maybe 5x the price in labor as it would be for the material.

Op this part is a bit confusing from both a design and manufacturing point of view.

>>2504465
The areas this poster highlighted are why this part is troublesome.

Why did you put a radius on that face of the teeth? (Red)
Why did you create a sharp obtuse angle where the teeth connect? (Green)

If these features are not totally necessary, or could be removed by altering a different part of your build, your part would be much easier to machine.

Also your tolerance of +/- 0.1mm for the whole part is kind of showing your inexperience. For this part to do what I think it's doing, you only need that level of precision on four features, the outer diameter circularity and runout, and the location of your holes. That is assuming a massive rpm that actually requires that precision. 0.1mm (.0039in) or what a machinist would call "four thou"(sand) is like Intel circuit board or Ferrari cylinder precision. You could probably loosen that up to 0.010in, which will also make your part much more doable for average machine shops running this kind of a part on a 3 axis HAAS.

As it stands this part well require 5 axis machining and cost thousands of dollars.
If you can remove the face radius, and add an end mill friendly radius to your teeth connections, you could run this part on a 3 axis machine for less than a thousand.

t. Design ME

posts.com:
3D printing and casting (especially sand casting) will not hold 0.1 tolerance without massive engineering efforts. The surface roughness of most 3D printed parts is not even good enough to measure to that level. Even if you would mill it to aerospace tolerances most plastics will move over time and humidity to be out of tolerance.

The only sane option is to adapt the fillets to be easily done on a 3 axis machine, reduce the need for small and non standard tools, so fillet all the inside corners in xy, only internal fillets in z and extra care where those meet, only specify tight tolerance for critical dimensions like the concentric bores, outside diameter, hole locations, no deep non standard bores or even better no deep bores at all and then try to fight something like the college shop mentioned or some hobby machinist or prepare to pay a few hundred $. Casting and 3D printing at home is fun but it's not really suitable for "engineered" parts and for sure this is not the right starting point for a beginner. Try sand casting a block within 1mm precision and you'll see what i mean.

On the plus side 0.1mm in alu should be doable on a good router so model maker guys may be able to help.

>The English statute mile was established by a Weights and Measures Act of Parliament in 1593 during the reign of Queen Elizabeth I. The act on the Composition of Yards and Perches had shortened the length of the foot and its associated measures, causing the two methods of determining the mile to diverge.[25] Owing to the importance of the surveyor's rod in deeds and surveying undertaken under Henry VIII,[26] decreasing the length of the rod by 1⁄11 would have amounted to a significant tax increase. Parliament instead opted to maintain the mile of 8 furlongs (which were derived from the rod) and to increase the number of feet per mile from the old Roman value.[27] The applicable passage of the statute reads: "A Mile shall contain eight Furlongs, every Furlong forty Poles,[n 3] and every Pole shall contain sixteen Foot and an half."[29] The statute mile therefore contained 5,280 feet or 1,760 yards.[19]

>>2500618
>The metric system is based largely on something abstract – numbers
That reflects the relationship between units but not the basis of scaling those units. The meter was based on 1/40,000,000 the polar circumference of the Earth, even though the official definition has changed to more precisely-measurable things since then. The foot is based on the approximate size of a man's foot (e.g. there are traditional statistical procedures to get a measure that is representative of the local population), and similar units called feet in the local language appear around the world. The main competitor here is the cubit, which is based on the distance from a man's elbow to the middle finger. As with other traditional measures, they were divided in various ways to suit various purposes. Pic related measures dozens of fractional divisions down to 1/448 cubit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2501446
>the definition of an inch
Is not the same thing as what the unit "inch" is based on. The official definitions of various units have been changed from time to time for various purposes (generally to allow more consistent/precise references as technology improves and there is a demand for that) while keeping the actual units the same or nearly so.

So, why is the modern definition of an inch 25.4mm? Because the meter is technically well-defined for modern purposes (the distance traveled by light in a certain number of atomic state cycles in an atomic clock), and an exact conversion factor to metric units is better than not having one (as would be the case with a different empirical definition), so the specific number was chosen to give an "inch" that was compatible with existing inch use cases. As noted by >>2501495.

>thinking that "pintje" in Dutch is an english term or has anything to do with the unit
"Pint" in Dutch is "pint". It's a cognate that refers to the same unit, though historical reasons result in slightly different modern quantities. "Pintje" in Dutch is a diminutive form of "pint" and refers to a "small pint" as mentioned in the text. In practice, this is about a half-pint or "cup" which is also a useful unit for beverages. Which is why there's a non-metric term for that specific quantity in nominally metric Belgium.

You asked for the dimensions of a cube that HOLDS a gallon. A material object that holds a liquid has a wall thickness, which in the case of 14ga sheet metal is about 1/16 of an inch. So yes, if you want to build a cube that actually holds a liquid, and have 14ga sheet metal with which to do it, you need to make the sides of the sheet metal squares larger than the cube root of 231 inches in order to actually produce that gallon capacity (6 1/4 inches to three significant figures). Actual liquid containers in the real world are not cube shaped, and instead use more complex geometries that work better for engineering considerations like internal pressure and drainage.

But not cubes. It's trivial to produce a non-cubic box shape with a gallon capacity with rational dimensions. Pick literally any two whole-number inch dimensions and calculate the third. Correct. If yo have a square-shaped piece of land, it is already a particular number of acres, whatever that is. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2502623
Because the gallon used in the US is descended from the "wine gallon", a unit used to measure wine, and apparently scaled to be 8 Troy pounds of wine. Meanwhile, the pound mostly descends from grain weight measurements, and the version that caught on in the US is the Avoirdupois pound, which is scaled a little differently. So different purposes for the different units. Additionally, the Imperial gallon is about 10 pounds of water, and at various times something tantamount to that was incorporated into the official definition.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Does anybody here actually, genuinely work extensively with both metric and SAE and prefer SAE? I'm looking for genuine thoughts, other than the fact that it's a front by europoors to deprive us of our freedom or whatever. I'm from northern Minnesota, but I've been doing engineering work for companies based in southern Canada for decades, so we have to use both systems interchangably. I have a few questions for those who claim their allegiance to SAE. I'm genuinely trying to understand what the hidden elegance of the SAE system is that must exist for people to like it so much.

What's up with the naming switch at 1/4" from fractional machine threads to numbered machine threads (which is confusingly identical to the entirely unrelated collection of wood/masonry/self-tapping/lag screws)? Is it because fractions below that point become unweildy? If so, I agree, but I think they're unwieldy above that point too. It seems to me like a poor imitation of the metric system.

What's up with lbm and lbf? And slugs? Having your nominal weight measurement *include* the acceleration from gravity just breaks things for no reason. Does anybody see why this is useful?

Any truly complex engineering in the SAE system is basically impossible. Every firm I know of, including ours, converts everything to metric the moment we have to do anything more complicated than a single free-body-diagram.

And then there's the more common complaints that people in this thread have already covered extensively, so I won't repeat, but I run into these every. single. day.

I'm not just trying to rip on the SAE system, I'm genuinely looking to understand why people like it so much.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2514297
>It seems to me like a poor imitation of the metric system.
Rather, those standards were made by the people developing those technologies in the first place, and different industries came up with different standards to suit their purposes (some of which reference relevant gauge sizes, which typically follow an approximately exponential relationship that breaks up a wide range of sizes into usefully distinct chunks).

>What's up with lbm and lbf?
The term "pound" was used for both situations before situations calling for differentiation become common.

>And slugs?
A slug is a unit of mass which is accelerated at one foot per second squared by a force of one pound-force acting on it.

>Does anybody see why this is useful?
Probably the people who use bathroom scales marked in kilograms rather than Newtons. For all sorts of purposes on Earth's surface, the correspondence between mass and weight makes that relationship naturally useful.

>Any truly complex engineering in the SAE system is basically impossible.
Care to give an example?

Monotube is easier since no welding and for smol engines should be sufficient. If it isn't it's easy to make another stage.

Then do something far more valuable than a boiler, learn and practice TIG welding and copy success. There are many good posts by professional welders in real welding forums (this will never be one because the 4chan board design is for brief convos) who do it for a living.

It's a toy not a tool after all so using a toy to learn a useful remunerative skill you can either be paid for or barter for stuff is pure win. You already know by experience how other projects develop skill.

A lift arc rig and a DC stick welder are proven as they can be. We trained many welders that way because pedals are mostly for fab shops and not every machine has a remote. This canonical thread shows how it's done and it's quite affordable.

These LEDs always need a driver, without one, the LED would die very fast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't know enough about electronic circuitry to tell you what each of those components are, however I doubt the flashing of the strobe function is controlled directly by the main processor or whatever. It seems logical that it's a situation where there's a dedicated component that provides the strobe effect, much like a blinker relay on a car, and when the device is switched to the right mode it routes the power through that component.

My suggestion is to put the flashlight into strobe mode, and then use a jumper wire to bridge each individual component to test them. When you bridge the correct one that's responsible for the strobing, the light should turn from strobing to steady on. Or at least mostly steady since some of the juice might still be going through the strobe component rather than the jumper wire.

Anyway, you would then have identified the component responsible for the strobing, so get a soldering iron and remove that component and replace it with a wire between the two contact the component was soldered to. It would still be the same amount of button clicks to go through all the modes, however the strobe mode would not just be a steady on mode instead.

I could also be completely wrong and jumping random components could also fry the whole device, but then it's a shitty $2 chink flashlight so who cares.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518345
And looking at how things are routed, nothing on the board connected to the battery should have anything to do with it since it's just feeding power to the switch board, it's probably just battery charging/management on that board. And there can't be anything having to do with mode switching located on the LED board since it just has power in and power out. So everything concerning the modes should be on that switch board. My guess is that small component labeled 2A2 (or ZAZ?) is either some sort of relay/mosfet to create the strobe mode, or a resistor to create the low beam mode. I'd say bypass that and see what happens.

>>2509382
see pic rel for basic idea that applies to all pieces I made. I dunno how you would print that. Gonna paste my an explanation

It consists of a backer plate (9 light + 9 heavy layers), porcelain shards and a topper (3 +3) encasing the ceramics. Wanted to use 2 offset layers of ceramics, instead I placed the first and additional shards on what I deemed crucial parts of the armor.

This is the basic method for all armor parts I made, a full plate with porcelain for my mask, forearms and torso, the rest consists only of the backer type plate, 18 layers of sandwiched light and heavy glass cloth.

Made a visor from 1cm thick polycarbonat. Went trough some trial and error while attempting to heat bend it. Made a bubble free curved piece with our oven, the trick is to heat it up to 150c first and frequently open the door to let out steam, after a while turn it up to 175c. I want to thank thermoplastic anon for that info again. Another thanks to soap bar anon, scrub a bar of soap then wipe with a dry towel on glassy surfaces like glasses you don't want to fog up with your breath, it really works.

>>2509676
show examples of how this could be made, 3d printers are definetevly cool, but I noticed a trend where people will simply assume that a printer can print anything. How would you measure out your face this way? I did with simple gypsum bandages. And then print it how? Carbon fibres? For costs, a 33cm x 33cm rectangle plate costs about 15€ in material costs, the groin plate has this size. thats 9 + 9 patches of the heavy a d light glass filament. 1m2 can be cut into 9 patches. 1m2 of glass weave costs about 3-5€, so about 3 for the light and 5 for the heavy, 8€ total for the weave. Epoxy resin can be expensive, cheapest I found was 11€ per kg. for a 33cmx33cm plate with 18 layers of mixed weaves I needed 750g of epoxy, so about 7-9€ or something. Now you got a basic plate for what 15-20€. Porcelain is the best worst ceramic for balistic protection, you can source that for free. Add another glass weave for spalling protection above that to stop porcelain fragments from flying everywhere and boom you got a decent plate I'd say. 25€ max.

>>2511923
the protective gear part is a different beast. the orthopaedic gear is to prevent knee injury from missteps or non optimal posture. same goes for the lumbar belt.
even the cheap aldi versions do their job.

joint injury is the number one eliminator of modern troops.

for the fit: add a padded comfortable belt strap with some semi-rigid plate support. this way you circumvent the spine being loaded and free your lungs more. putting padding on the shin lower side, so it rests better on the shoe, can make the bug a feature.

some light knee pads could help with the armor and hard knuckle or sand gloves would add some necessary hand protection.

for the groin plate: try to cut it int an inverted trapezoid (basicly upside down chest plate shape). then it moves more easily when walking. the two removed pieces can be added as belt flaps/ armor skirt pieces.

For maximum efficiency, cut the fat out and chop it into ~1cm cubes. Put it in a pot with some water to cover and heat it to a simmer. After a few hours all the fatty acids will be rendered out of the tissue, then you sift the chunks out and let the liquids harden. The fat layer separates and floats on the water. To clean it just scrape the grimy bits off the bottom of the solid fat layer and put it back in a pot with fresh water and a generous handful of salt, bring it to a simmer and stir it a bit, let it cool and repeat until pearly white. Finally melt the fat down and insert a wick. There you go, odorless human candle.
Human fat is about 7700kcal/kg which is a lot better than wood pellets which generally sit around 4300kcal/kg. You only need a small fraction of that energy to refine it.

>>2517250
To make soap all you need to do is weigh your human tallow, then bring it to about 50°C. Take 26.82% of your fat weight in distilled water and 13.41% in pure lye and dissolve it in the water (do it with good ventilation or die). It will heat to almost boiling so let the mixture come down to around 50°C also, then dump it in the liquid fat and blend it with an immersion blender until it turns into a sort of paste. Scoop that out into whatever mold you like and let it sit for a day, then demold it and let it air dry for 2-4 weeks.
