Why teflon? Why bedliner for bonding? Line X actually is bombproof, mythbusters made a vid about that, discussed this in thread #1 or 2 I think. The company by the same name actually has a specialized type of coating called pax- something. They use that for bombproofing government buildings. But you can't simply buy either of these products in a can. A shame. Only certified paintshops who are in contract with Line - X get that stuff and are allowed to coat projects wih it.

For the teflon, I just don't know what it would acclompish. I've seen a vid where a dude made a pauldron with glass filament + carbon fibre layers. But carbon sucks. Glass fibre cloth is simply the cheapest.

I wrote ZNA productions and techthisoutmeow multiple times, donated to their patreon. Wanted them to build and shoot test panels with my method. Mentioning it again, 9 light + 9 heavy layers and additionally porcelain + another 3 heavy and 3 light ontop. No further responses for about two months or so.

But thankfully a german hansguns offered to test it for me, I'll be sending him 2 such testpanels after xmas. I've gained some doubts of the success of my plates delivering what I hope for, because I did something different. I didn't vacuum press the plates during curing. My theory is, the epoxy itself should stay where it is and not be pressed out excessively. Further, I think a pressed conventional plate has it disadvantages too. The layers are already then pressed together and it' s maybe easier to penetrate them this way.

Only live tests will show if my theoretical method has advantages over singular type of weave pressed plates. If I had something like military interest funding, I'd research this matter more troughly, but I'm a literal neet lmao.

>>2519137
I have made a few hunting cabins and guest houses using timber framed cob with adobe/lime plaster. They work really well for the summer and okay for winters. The only thing to watch out for is leaving the sills unprotected/untreated like in my first pic. You also need to know before hand where you are going to hang up heavy objects and plan appropriately. Cob isn't very good for holding heavy objects, but you CAN carve into the walls and make indents for holding items.
If you live in a really cold climate, I highly suggest looking into haybale homes because they insulate a lot better due to being thicker. No, bugs aren't an issue as long as you pack the bales with clay and plaster them properly.

Thread reducer insert (or bushing).

The way you can tell its not a typical insert used to reinforce a hole is that there's no slot or other provision for driving them, or notches to make them self threading like the inserts used for wood.
These get hand threaded over a too small threaded stud or machine screw until they cant turn anymore, and then that assembly is screwed into a threaded hole as one piece.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518925
>If you put on new discs you put on new pads. You change discs and pads together.
Important point, this. New (flat) discs on old (roughed) pads means less surface contact means less braking force. Until the peaks on the old pads wear away.
Amusingly, old discs and new pads is the same thing. Except the pattern on the disc very quickly carves its pattern into the pads, causing an immediate huge amount of wear.

>>2516707
try again...

>>2516392
I try to salvage all components, that have honestly saved me a fortune, some of my more complex projects used mosfets and h-bridge and even Z80 chips that are almost 50SARs (13.30USD) here, i think i mentioned this b4 but all the caps I used i got from an old trashed amp, most modern electronic components are fairly resilient and can handle moderate heat (100c-350c) in short intervals just fine, but i wouldn't say the same about board substrate, especially the older boards which use cotton paper resin composite or phenolic resins which really don't like the temperature getting above 380c for too long as they tend to puff up or crack or burn.
personally i use a manual solder pump and wick for most salvage work to not stress the board or component, but for stuff i really don't want to damage i have a a goot TP-100 de-soldering gun that I use for that stuff, its not ideal but at least i have some temperature control that I don't have with my soldering iron which tends to drift up as i am working from (~345c-430c) or even higher if not used for some time a while plugged in, which is usually not a problem when i am de-soldering for salvaging and idc about the pcb, but during rework it tents to be a pain to work around, a wet sponge helps knock the temp down 10 or so degrees but it is really hard to gauge the temp without constantly checking it with thermocouple. my iron is gr8 60% of the time when i am doing anything else, but just makes my life a nightmare in that other 40%(which is rework), it is a goot TQ-95 for reference.

>using a shitty non temperature controlled iron
There's absolutely nothing wrong with non temperature controlled soldering irons. I use a 5 Euro 60 watt soldering iron from China (see image) which I've modded with a 3 Euro dimmer switch AND I solder lead free. Before I modded it with the dimmer switch I just plugged it out and back in to reach my preferred temperature and prevent it from overheating the tips.

So yes, it's a skill issue and >>2516707 is right.

Stop blaming your tools and lack of money. You can buy a 60 watt temperature controlled soldering iron from China for 5 Euro, shipping included.
They are perfectly fine too.

posts.com:
Already using the system on our current house. installed it all ourselves. we generate about 40% of our power. running since March.

we have 2 load panels (breaker boxes) in our house. one is original, one installed by us. the one we installed is SOLAR ONLY. the two DO NOT CROSS in any way. our solar load panel is 100% off-grid. no grid-tie.

this powers 40% of our house. the rest is on grid.

when we move into the new house we are building, we will expand solar system. our aim is to be self sufficient in two to three years. house should be complete in 3-4 months.

current array is 2440 W. we have 8 FLA batteries wired 4s2p. running on a Sol-Ark 12k charge controller inverter.

upgrade will include switching to LiFePo4 batteries. 3x Fortress Eflex. we will add more as cash flow allows. we live debt-free, so no financing.

this powers:
2 chest freezers

air handler motor

hall lights

What these anons are referring to is titanium's nasty tendency to work/strain harden. When you bend/deform a piece of material, you expect it to get weaker, right? Not titanium. When you bend, cut, or drill into titanium, it gets significantly stronger. All ductile materials do this to some extent, but titanium gets SIGNIFICANTLY stronger in strain hardening than pretty much everything else.

posts.sub: What went wrong with my soap?
posts.com:
This batch had 9.5% pine tar in it by weight and was soaped at 130 degrees to encourage gel phase. The soap, despite being liquid as the tar was being added, instantly seized and turned lumpy after the tar and hydroxide were added even with minimal stirring.

I mixed the soap to as homogenous of a mixture as I could get before adding cedar wood extract and charcoal powder which caused it to separate and seize again. Despite this I still tried to make the soap become homogenous again and then molded it.

After setting in the mold for 2 days the soap came out reeking of old car tires and disappointment. It was also leaking a substantial amount of rancid oil which came out in rivers as I cut the soap. Most disappointingly the soap was filled with balls of acrid smelling tar which had failed to mix despite it looking homogenous when molded.

Did I simply use too much tar? Should I have melted the tar and fats together instead of adding it with the hydroxide?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: maybe next time skip the rancid oil and acrid smelling tar idk that's just me but i'd try it without those ingredients couldn't hurt you know?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: why tar?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520204
-Mix the pine tar in with the rest of the melted oils before adding the lye mixture.

-Use a lower temp like 70-80F instead of 130F. Pine tar soaps cook off really fast and with minimal stirring compared to other soaps. This probably didn't work in your favor either.

-Make sure that you're considering the pine tar as an oil when you calculate your lye amount.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507298
Well, they're like other heat engines in that to get more power out, you have to raise the compression. The big advantage internal combustion engines have is that they run at high compression "for free" - a comparable Stirling needs to be pumped up to pressure before running or be a sealed pressurized design. There's nothing stopping you from building one that uses higher compression other than the engineering involved.
Swedish submarines (Gotland class) use Stirling engines instead of diesels, so they're not just toys.
I could be wrong, haven't looked at the subject in a few years.

>>2509786
There were lots of small improvements made in the 1930s and 1940s when they were more widely used. Unfortunately it seems like most of the knowledge is spread out among communities that don't talk to each other.
For example, there are a few people in Sweden who drive gasifier-fueled cars, and every single one of them use a "stacked pancakes" fabric filter (a large "sock" that is tied off around wireframe discs; used to be canvas cloth in the 1940s, nowadays it's fibreglass). I've never seen for example Americans use fabric filters. Burgers all seem to use the Wayne Keith design, but the details are a trade secret and nobody outside of the US has heard of it.
The basics should be the same though, and there are some obvious things like insulating the hearth (firebox?) and using a heat exchanger for the air intake that I would do.
Another thing would be to convert a modern electric hybrid car. The pros and cons of a gasifier and a battery vehicle means they would complement each other pretty well.

Cyclones filter out particles; they are heavier than the gas and get flung to the outer wall and fall down. The intended use is that they catch most of what comes out so that the filters clog up less often.
Dealing with tar is mostly done, from what I've seen, by minimizing production (right fuel, right temperature) and cooling the gas before it reaches the engine.

I've researched a ton on steam engines, but I've slowly realized there are too many reasons gas engines are superior. Steam engines become very complicated when trying to make them competitive. Most people aren't going to mess with steam boilers (regardless of whether the design is safe), while steam generators require precise controls. Most burner designs have the flame quenched by the boiler/generator with a lot of unburnt fuel appearing as smoke. Ideally, only the exhaust should make contact with the boiler/generator. COGAS (Combined Gas and Steam) engines actually uses the exhaust of a gas turbines to heat a boiler and are among the most efficient combustion engines out there. Going back to using turbines for wood, you'd also use a separator like you would for wood gasifiers, the only difference is all the heat is concentrated in one operation for a higher thermal efficiency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517210
>What do you mean by efficiency here?
Power vs. fuel consumption

>having a cold gas at the start of the cycle increases the difference in temperature and therefore pressure.
Having a colder temperature would increase the efficiency of the Carnot cycle if delta T remains constant. However, delta T is purely a function of the amount of fuel burnt, heat capacity, and heat lost to the surroundings. A slower burn is going to lose more heat to the surroundings and an incomplete burn means less fuel burnt. In practice, a slower burn is also going to have less room to expand, and less work will be recovered from it, but a Carnot engine doesn't have any notion of a stroke or expansion ratio.

>>2504527
I wonder how hard it would be to make methanol from wood or coal syngas. You can convert gasoline engines to methanol rather easily.

There's a 99.8% selective methanol synthesis from carbon monoxide and hydrogen with a copper and zinc oxides catalyst at engine cylinder pressures (750~1500 PSI) and kitchen oven temperatures (250C / 500F). It can also work with carbon dioxide and hydrogen or carbon monoxide and water, since CO2 and H2O are intermediates in the process.

Apart from methanol being a gasoline substitute, there's also a simple dehydration reaction with solid acid catalysts (such as gamma alumina) at the same temperature and pressure conditions to produce dimethyl ether. DME has very similar handling characteristics to propane, and is non-toxic and non-corrosive and can be burned for heating and cooking, but also works well in diesel engines (with some conversion required, obviously).

These processes seem like they should be simple enough for small factories run by an individual or small team. Not too much harder than the combination of wood gas conversions and moonshining, and you get fuels that can be handled, stored, sold, and generally used for all the same things as today's standard fuels. You can make them from fire wood in the countryside, coal in coal country, and if solar panels keep getting cheaper, eventually from electrolysis hydrogen and CO2 from chemical capture methods or biomass (you can still get CO2 out of biomass you can't easily burn properly for energy).

The toxicity of methanol isn't that much worse than gasoline. Its reputation for toxicity is mainly from people mistaking it for ethanol and drinking it with enthusiasm. DME is basically non-toxic.

Butanol is attractive in several ways (including its gasoline-like energy density), but since it's produced by fermentation, it's a much more finicky, picky process. You probably can't make it from coal or electrolysis hydrogen, except by complex synthesis no easier than gasoline. Furthermore, the fermentation process only works on cellulose, it'll do little to nothing with lignin, which is a major component of wood.

Not him, but offshore drilling rigs, fracking rigs, and refineries are all complex operations dependent on sophisticated industry and the cooperation of many people. In a breakdown of social order, they could easily cease operation.

Cutting firewood and strip-mining coal are relatively unsophisticated by comparison, and as a regular average dumbass, you can probably participate in them in an energy crisis. Even mining coal with a pick and a shovel is surprisingly productive, probably better than cutting firewood with a chainsaw and a hydraulic splitter. And because we've largely moved on from firewood, there's a lot of energy saved up in the trees we haven't cared to cut down. American industry ran largely on firewood through most of the industrial revolution, because of those vast pre-industrial forests, and they have recovered quite well since we switched to oil and coal.

We're pretty careless with spending energy because it's so cheap, but if things go to shit, we've got to at least be able to keep the farms running, and the trains and riverboats, and short-haul trucking to get goods into the stores. Wood and coal can do that, with far from ideal social organization, if we're smart about it.

>Would anyone buy one if they were slower and heavier?
If the alternative is a bicycle, yes they will. European governments in particular are desperate to kill the combustion automobile without presenting a realistic alternative (ie, an alternative that isn't "just buy a tesla lol"). In 2030 when Germany bans internal combustion engines, 90% of the population will be facing the choice "shitty electric car" or "bicycle". Bicycle is well enough for young people and city dwellers, but families in cities with a population below 100k are going to need automobiles, and for most of them a shitbox that can get them from home to daycare to work to the store to the daycare and back home will be enough. People who commute longer distances are already rare in Europe, and most of them go by train or intercity bus anyway. The only Euro countries that have an American mentality of "forty minute commute by car is okay" are Sweden and Russia, both shitholes with a population density closer to antarctica than to central europe.
Today's idea of the future electric car is something like a Tesla, but the reality is that that level of comfort will be limited to the upper class. The middle class will need to buy cars worse than what the lower class is used to today, and the lower class will probably have to accept not owning a car at all in favour of some dystopian "timeshare subscription car". But when the alternative is no car at all, people will accept it. Yes you can get by with public transport in Europe, but it's slow, filthy, and uncomfortable, so most people will still want a car, even if it's a VW shitbox with one motor and a two tonne lead battery that tops out at 60km/h.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2518526
>Can we get a description of what's happening here?
Sure. I guess I should add some reference number. Essentially there are 3 circuits:
- the air circuit (hatched) that cools the mantle before being diluted with exhaust and then is fed into the reactor (bottom right)
- the wood gas circuit from the reactor going through tar absorbers and filter before going to the gas turbine, while being cooled by water
- the water circuit that goes in opposite direction to the wood gas circuit, picking up heat throughout the path, before being superheated in the spiral at the bottom of the reactor and then powers a steam turbine.

Lots of details (condencer, recuperator, waste extraction etc) are missing but I hope those are obvious anyway.
Wood in the first tar absorber is fed to the reactor through the yellow square chute at intervals, thus recycling the tar.

Basically I just pile it full of logs and ignite, it pipes the smoke through a chamber that heats water, which goes into the radiators and taps in my house. It has an old-fashioned thermostat hooked up to the air intake, so that as the water approaches a set temperature it will feed less air to the fire, and thus not boil the water and also keep the fire going. >>2520428
Airlocks aren't that complicated, you just need two doors.
>open outer door, combustion chamber is still sealed
>put fuel in loading chamber
>close outer door
>open inner door
>fuel falls into combustion chamber
>close inner door

You can also use a second airlock to remove ash, or you can have one engine with two combustion chambers, so you can open one right up while the system runs on the other.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519648

Shitty ESL explanation ahead:

With a conventional 2 stroke hammer, the rotational force of impact is being distributed evenly since the hammer has enough time to reset and go back into position. At high speeds the hammer inside the Hikoki keeps slipping. The rotational force isn't symmetrical anymore (especially bad since the strokes are offset by 120 degrees) and this causes the shaft of the screw to bend.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2519665
So it’s stil that 2/3 hammering thing? Like smacking it at 0/360, then skipping 120 and hitting it again at 240?

It’s strange because you would think it’s all just rotational and centered on an axis, even if it’s not hitting evenly, it’s still perpendicular force…but I guess at high speed it goes crazy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519667
Each stroke also puts some radial force onto the screw, therefore causing it to slightly bend out of center. This gets corrected with every successful stroke and is easily managed with both impacts offset by 180 degrees (standard).

Mind you, 3 strokes at 120 degrees can work perfectly fine but in the case of the Hikoki you'd have to install a tight af return spring which would probaly require too much strength to overcome, requiring more power and also causing more wear on the hammer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>1. Is there any real reason to spend big on a "high security" lock over your stock-standard cylinder? Are thieves really picking locks in the real world?
We've had business owners at my work ask us to put high-security locks on buildings with floor-to-ceiling glass walls and doors. The security level of your lock should match the security level of the rest of your security system. Most actual criminals (in America) don't bother to pick locks because it's a skill that requires patience, and if criminals had patience, they wouldn't be criminals. They're going to put in the least amount of effort possible. Your advantage as a homeowner is that you can control how high that lower limit is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518012
>Are thieves really picking locks in the real world?
not much, but what some theives do is make copies of keys from where they work after getting access to them legitimately as part of their job or by sneaking them off the premises and putting them back after getti g copies made.
Security locks minimize the ability to do this by restricting and documenting who gets blanks at the locksmith level, so if you keep close rein on who has a key you can minimize inside theft jobs by unknowns or disgruntled terminations using a spare key.
If a key gets away though you'll need to get new cylinders and keys, and some brands will remove restrictions on older blanks when they stop selling those models, or just after a decafe or so to force everyone to upgrade cylinders to maintain the security restrictions.
IOW its kind of like a subscription service that needs to be renewed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518012
>Is there any real reason to spend big on a "high security" lock over your stock-standard cylinder?
For a house, no. Stay away from bullshit electronic smart locks. A lot of them can be beaten with rare earth magnets, plus the backup cylinders are baby-tier easy to pick. I've seen people open fingerprint locks with a photocopy of someone's fingerprint. Just get a regular Schlage and remember to keep it locked.

>How difficult is it to replace a lock yourself, without having to pay a locksmith?
Very easy. All you need is a phillips screwdriver. Take the long screws out of the old one, pull it apart, replace the guts, slap the new one on and line it up, screw back together. I can do them in about 15 minutes.

>>2518024
This. Get a nice solid door, dead pin the hinges, and reinforce the frame to discourage kicking in.
Add some sort of basic alarm system. They even have sensors now that will alarm and text your phone if the door is opened. The more bullshit the crackheads have to get through the less likely they are to try.
Keep your drapes closed so they can't case your house or see your bigass TV. Don't put boxes from expensive things in your trash, find a dumpster somewhere to toss them in. Don't advertise that you have shit worth stealing. Make sure sliding doors and windows have nigger bars wedged in them so they can't be forced from outside.

>>2518096
Follow basic common sense. When you buy a new house change the locks immediately before you do anything else. You have no way of knowing how many people have the old keys.
For businesses make sure you get keys back if you fire someone and cancel their alarm codes as soon as they leave. For job boxes and other storage locks replace all of the locks a couple times a year. Don't reuse old locks just pitch em. Security cameras with offsite storage are a good idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Was a software engineer/systems analyst for about 15 years before starting a 1-person handyman business. Was good at fixing my own shit, found that I could make money fixing other people's shit, too. I enjoyed the problem-solving aspect of it (like my previous career,) got bored with some of the more mundane jobs. It was also nice being able to write off tools and equipment on my taxes.

I launched my business with a targeted postcard campaign, positioning myself as a knowledgeable DIYer who lived in the same community and was somebody like your neighbors and co-workers. I'm in an affluent suburb, so many people really liked dealing with me, versus some crusty old drunk who smelled like cigarettes and BO, or someone who didn't speak English very well.

Did it for about 12 years. By the end, I was charging around $70/hr and had all the work I could handle. But it's a grind to get in enough billable hours during a week to really make great money. Even though I was just a schmuck-in-a-truck, there's overhead ($1M liability policy, business licenses, supplies, transportation etc.) and it's not always possible to consistently log 6-8 hours per day, 5-6 days per week. I always told people who asked, "This job isn't paying my mortgage." My wife has a lucrative career that carried most of major expenses.

But the physical toll finally got to be too much. Moving from a desk job to something that physical, I wasn't really ready for it. After 12 years, I had developed arthritis in both thumbs that made many jobs very painful. As I got into my 50s, I was less comfortable on high ladders, and just kind of got tired of the whole grind.

Someone stronger, with more stamina, and a higher pain threshold could do well, though. If you're halfway careful about what you do, stick to things you know are within your skills, take the time to research fixes, and don't cheap out on materials and tools, you'll soon have a list of people clamoring for your services.

Do a business case study, list what you can reasonably expect to earn (best and worst case, with say a 5 year projection) after expenses if you do it full time. Make sure you assess every expense and risk. Then check if you can (in worst case) do it for the first year or two without going broke (ie what your exposure is). If the result is good, do it. As for the risks, a one year resume hole isn’t that bad for a senior engineer.

There should be some examples online because many banks require this kind of business plan before they give out loans

>>2510270
>>2510586
exhibits work varies heavily museum size and subject. I work at a science museum, so a lot of what I generate is the actual content, vs a fine art museum where art handling and conversation is more emphasized over making stuff. I don't work at this museum, but Exploratorium in SF has a lot of info about their exhibits and development on their website, if you wanna poke around: https://www.exploratorium.edu/exhibits/exhibit-making

The big draw is being able to "make cool stuff," which starts with getting stuff paid for. Museums have shoestring budgets and there's a whole team to secure donations and grants and the like. This means what we get to do is guided by who is willing to pay to have their name on it, and then informed by what the educators and scientists want to have on the floor. I like working within these constraints; I think its easier to be creative with limitations.

Maintenance and repair is a big part of my job, since the general public will destroy your shit very efficiently. When something new goes out on the floor usually I learn what I forgot to reenforce or what misuse case I forgot to consider almost instantly. It's not the public's fault, they paid for this experience and they are just trying to have fun. Repairing museum exhibits is a lot of creative problem solving since every piece is super custom. I end up learn shit like pool repair, and then apply it to the water table exhibit piece. I also end up with a ton of different trade tools in my workshop, since sometimes I'm doing woodworking, welding, plumbing, electrical, lighting, masonry and painting. This isn't the kind of job where you can just lock in a single trade and be good at it forever. I'm always going to be a novice at a bunch of different things.

Also, the pay is shit, so you have to really love what you're doing. I know that sounds hokey but its true.

Happy to answer specific questions if you guys have them.

Sometimes you have to lose a day to make them happy. If a customer loves you they will almost certainly talk to their friends about you and then it is game over. Don't be afraid to only work within the wheelhouse you've mastered or be honest with customers about inexperience

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The back and sides are melamine. It's a pretty shit product to pocket hole or attempt to screw with any kind of security. It's fine for nailer boards like mounting uppers with pan head screws. But there it's simply sandwiched between the screw and the wall.
If you attempt to pull things together by going into the melamine with a screw, it will tear out almost immediately. MDF even is much stronger.

I would glue up with silicone. This will hold until you decide to peel things apart again then can be scraped off. Most cabinets have a corner clip of plastic or wood and you simply screw up into the countertop. A bead of silicone across the top surface would be plenty here. It doesn't need to be a fancy caulk job.

>>2514282
Technically, all you need is an appropriately sized file and some patience.
Failing that, there are quite a few options, any one of which would depend on
>your budget
>your machine(s) (if any)
>the fixturing and indexing you have available on the machine(s) we have no way of knowing that you own
>the type of gear to be made
>the material you want to make the gear out of
>the gear's size
>the number of teeth
>and so on
You might as well have gone into /fa/ and said
>novice here, what tool do i need to make shoes manually? i have an idea for a sneaker i want to try
Where do you retards come from?
Why are there so many of you?
Why are you all retarded in the exact same way?
What is keeping you from dying in retarded catastrophes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2514282
Depends on the type of gear and the tooth profile. For simple spur gears the best options are shaper and horizontal milling machine. A vertical mill could also do the job, but the set up would be a bit awkward and a lot less rigid than a horizontal. In all cases you need an indexing fixture. For milling processes you would need to purchase the correct cutter for your desired pitch. With a shaper you just need a single point tool, which you could probably grind by hand.

It's a false economy, intensely retarded and unlikely to work well, and the way you see machines and money is broken. If you really want a lathe then do the needful. Old CNC shit is cheap for good reasons.

Bring money, have rigging gear handy so your cash buys machines instead of someone else's labor then relentlessly hunt deals. Be willing to drive long distance and own or rent suitable truck and trailer. Hydraulic drop decks are rentable and insanely nice.

posts.com:
You have a couple of options. Hpa tank at 3000-4500 psi regulated down for your nailgun pressure or co2 regulated down for your nailgun pressure. Look at paintball setups as it is essentially the same thing you want to recreate.

If you are doing a bunch of rapid nailing, the co2 can and will freeze shit up.

As the the poster above mentioned co2 had a lot of capacity at a lower pressure because it is stored as a LIQUID (guy above said gas, but i assume he really meant liquid) so it boils off producing a ton of gas for the container size. Unfortunately that also means it gets cold and can freeze up.

Like i said look to paintball gun accessories, bottomline adapters, regulators, and tanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518231
> Also, is there any reason to not use a cut 4x4, I've heard you should cut down 2x4s and rotate the endgrain so it doesn't make a circle pattern but I'm not sure why

Wood warps, it bends towards the center-side of the board (so that the end grain makes a U-shape). If you rotate them end glue them back to back the warping forces cancel out and the wood stays straighter. But it only really matters if you put it outside. For indoor use a full beam is fine, but glueing up 2 2x4s to make a 4x4 is fine too.

If all you have is a saw, the trick is to glue 2x4s together, but cut one of them in pieces, and you have a free ‘lap joints’ without needing a chisel. You just glue pieces of 2x4 onto another 2x4 and leave exactly 4” of space between the pieces. It may not look very professional but it’s the strongest ‘beginner joint’ you can make

I used 4x4s as posts in my power rack. I regularly slam 140+kg sideways into it. Wood, even shitty softwood like fir, is extremely strong along the grain. The important thing to the structural integrity of a table is that you prevent it from racking, which you do by shortening the lever arm to your joints. The board you placed on the back of the desk that intersects all the legs and the tabletop is an excellent way of doing that. Other than that it's just absurdly overbuilt unless you live in an active war zone and want it to survive bombings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520279
It'd be perfectly stable with just 2x4s but aesthetically it'd be very different. I wouldn't build it with either if I'm being honest. At current prices I'd just build it out of beech (because I'm in Scandinavia, don't build furniture with American beech) because frankly the price difference isn't that big and furniture that gets heavily used shouldn't be built out of softwood. Furthermore you'd need considerably less hardwood and could build it in the sleek style. Construction lumber adds another dimension of suck because it's not properly dried and will twist and bend a lot as it dries naturally over the next year. You can alleviate that somewhat by laminating 2x4s into 4x4s if you want to keep the bulky aesthetic. I don't know about America but here we don't have 2x2s and the closest stuff we do have is bottom shelf garbage wood not suitable for anything.
If you build the table as you showed in your OP out of a hardwood then it will plenty sturdy. If you go the whole nine yards and laminate the legs instead of just joining 2 edges and then join the aprons in with mortises and tenons then it will be extremely strong. Also, I know this is going to sound backwards but a medium hardwood like European beech is so much easier to work with hand tools than softwood. Construction lumber is very low grade lumber full of knots and defects making it even worse to work with, plus it has rounded corners that you need to plane off which takes a human age to do by hand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520318
That's a fair point. Mortise and tenon joints vary wildly in strength based on fitment and for an apron to stiffen the frame it needs to be very precisely matched and glued over as large a side-grain surface as possible. For desks, the aprons are really just a better looking set of knee braces and on a desk it's usually excluded or dramatically reduced on the front face for both function and form; and you can get away with that because the top works with the side and back aprons to prevent twisting, so the back apron functions as knee braces for both the back and the front.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2497894
I've been down this road before. Don't do it. Electrical stuff is the absolute worst to try to keep organized, since every type of thing (resistors, caps, connectors, fuses, relays, ICs, sensors, LEDs, the list goes on) has 100 different subtypes, and often each one of those subtypes has a subsubtype. When you start putting shit in tackle boxes, unless you're very careful about how you organize it, you might as well throw it away, because you're never going to see it again.

I've found the best way to avoid clutter and minimize "forgotten items" is to maximize literal visibility of your stuff. Genuinely, taking the doors off of a bunch of my floor-to-ceiling storage cabinets was one of the smartest things I've ever done. Those harbor freight small parts organizers can be a blessing and a curse. If you're going to use one, you need to label each drawer, otherwise it just becomes a garbage container, and you might as well throw it away.

>>2497889
you're gonna want a multi-layer approach for top hoarding. First you line the walls with peg-board. Then at chest level you're gonna want work-bench tier table/shelving that goes along the sides of the work room. You can then subdivide the lower sections into actual drawers or cubby hole spaces for large containers or tool chests. Now since you didnt finish the cieling you're gonna wanna get some cordage and hang stuff off of it, like baskets full of gloves and shit. We arent done yet, because that ladder in the corner can be used to access the rafters, where you are going to shove all the shit you will never use but dont want to throw away up there. Get some 2x6s and make some light shelves that fit between the rafters. Dont put anything heavy up there though, because realistically the framing of your roof isnt designed to hold weight in that direction but its fine if its just a few hundred pounds. probably.

posts.sub: Retrofitting a light tower trailer generator
posts.com: I've been thinking of modifying a light tower trailer ever since I came across a Kubota D1105T a few months back. The idea was to retrofit a trailer with the aforementioned engine and power my house and potentially remote cabin. Recently I bought a light tower trailer with a Kubota D905 and 6kW gen head and have been cleaning it up. The idea is to ditch the 6kW head and upgrade, while installing the Kubota D1105T in place. Had a few questions for anyone who knows these engines pretty well, or had this type of idea. Both of the engines above come from different applications. The Kubota D905 engine has a mfg sticker mentioning 'constant speed only'. I've disassembled the engine far enough to compare the governor assemblies and I'm stuck scratching my head. Seemingly the only factors keeping the smaller engine at a "constant speed" are the throttle control screws on the outside of the engine. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Load will determine the final rpm. You can lock any throttle position on both of those engines or vary them.

Cooling can be an issue in overloaded diesel engines so additional airflow over the radiator may be necessary.

>>2518032
Depends on the task, but apparently I am an odd one given the replies so far, but I like ratcheting screwdriver with bits. But it is hard to find a good one, honestly still looking the good one broke after several years and the new versions aren't as good. Lots of them now have hollow handles for storage, but that really weakens it as the handle bends and sometimes even breaks in my hand when I grip too hard, the old metal ones never did that. Reason I still like them is I have had projects where I drive in hundreds and hundreds of screws by hand. I had bits wear out which lead to other problems. By switch to fresh bits as I go I didn't have to keep buying screw drivers which cost more then a box of bits. It also lets me change to other types as the job had 8 screw types, so finding a comfy handle each item was annoying. Lastly the ratcheting helped for some oddly positioned screws, but you want fine gear teeth so you don't waste a lot of the rotation.

I also have regular screwdrivers as well for the more detail work as they aren't loose.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2516497
>is it fine if I intend to redo it properly in a year?
Half-assing a job makes sense if it's fairly simple, or if it results in a huge savings of time or effort.
This seems like you'd be doing 75% of the job anyway, just to re-do it all over again in a year.

If it's a matter of finances, and you just can't afford the materials to do it right, then that might make sense to do with what you can afford. But putting in 175% of the work effort isn't a "lazy" way to do a thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Laziest is the biggest interlocking permeable concrete blocks you can get. Because soil and grass grows inside, the grass roots will assist in the stabilisation of the blocks and help hold them together, the large foot print means pedestrian weight is distributed so much the resistance of soil alone without hardcore base is enough to minimise sinking and tilting.
use physics and nature to work in your favour, and you will have to do less work to overcome them. A lazy life needs a little thinking, but worth it to have more comfy time

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pavers right on dirt will move and be unlevel almost immediately. Also it’s a huge pain in the ass to scrape all the mud and crap off each individual one when you go to do it right.
Larger flag stones won’t shift as easy but still the same problem with becoming unlevel over time. Also huge pain to level dirt. Much easier to just dig down a little bit, put down sharp sand, compact and screed, then lay the flagstones.
Pavers will need something to retain them like in your picture, I prefer concrete around them once laid.
If there will be heavy stuff like cars on it, you’ll need to dig deeper, put down road base, compact (ideally with a powered compactor) then thin layer of sharp sand, compact again, screed and lay. Too shallow a back fill or not enough compacting and it will get ruts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Menards used to be a great place for hand tools.
Masterforce sockets and wrenches used to be made in the USA by Danaher (same OEM that used to make USA craftsman)
Their whole huge selection of master force screwdrivers were made in the USA by Western Forge (another former Craftsman OEM)

Next to the admittedly expensive masterforce USA sockets and ratchets sat loose Gearwrench sockets and wrenches(medium priced), and Crescent sockets and wrenches (dirt cheap, Apex tools same as gear wrench)

You could get a full 15pc SAE and 15pc metric Crescent combination wrench set for $40 each on sale. And they were NICE. Great fit and finish, didn’t have a lobster claw, high end polished chrome. Way better than their price suggested and the king of budget wrenches.
Loose wrenches were also very cheap, none of this 9$ for a single 1/2 wrench shit, like $2.50.
Sockets felt long, fat and light like Kobalts do, but were probably fine, I always bought gear wrench or masterforce sockets instead though.

Master force dropped danaher as an Oem, western forge is dead, they stopped carrying gear wrench and crescent
They now have a full master force section that’s some off the wall random Chinese Oem for all their sockets wrenches and screwdrivers.
And it all costs more now too

I don’t buy any masterforce hand tools anymore

As for my love of crescent branded combination wrenches, menards got a 7pc set in a holder and had it on door buster sale for 10$ a while back
Got it home and the wrenches have been completely changed, straight dogshit garbage that you expect cheap wrenches to be.
Not a surprise , they changed the crescent logo and I guess changed the wrenches for the worse at the same time.
So even if they did have a crescent display the new wrenches suck dick.
Gear wrench has steadily been going downhill, western forge isn’t even a company anymore.

The whole situation sucks as it’s only been like 3 years since it all changed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2516960
>requires a rod-shaped object to turn it which is better welded to the ends.

No it doesn't, you've never even touched one if you honestly believe that.
It operates by hand exactly like any other flat thumbscrew and merely gives you the option of using a rod if you want, or a crescent wrench.
It also lets you attach lanyard which is very helpful in the kinds of "grab something and go" kinds of jobs they're suited for.
The flat thumbscrew is way easier to develop leverage by hand than with the knob *especially* if the tool or your hands are wet or oily, and far better for visually guaging adjustments than a knob with no index marks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2516971
T-handles spin faster than a loop without nee to reposition fingers for each rotation.

The point of a stout T-handle is rapid pre-adjustment (hold tool in one hand, spin handle with opposite palm) then after placing the visegrip on the workpiece the T-handle facilitates applying MUCH more clamping force than a manual squeeze thanks to threadly mechanical advantage. I've modded mine for many years and my equally experienced (forty-plus years including fixing fighters, terrestrial vehicles, welding and machinig) bro liked mine so much he modded his ~20+ fleet too.

If want lanyard loop tack a nut to the handle. T-handles work far better than a small low leverage anything (besides welding I pull many delicious LS engines and 4L80E transmixerators at salvage.

Since you don't believe me you can do one for yourself easily enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I didn't bother snipping the L-shape off this one since it makes a fine spinner even wearing stick welding gloves. Use case makes esthetics irrelevant but my OCDbro cut his from a handy length of keystock and bothered to square then which is actually a functional disadvantage vs. a slight angle facilitating palm spinning.

Place palm on tip to spin and it's MUCH faster then fingerbanging any knob. Oils and grease are not an issue because there is no slippage.

Last time I posted one it triggered some crazy but they can CNC theirs if they like. It's also easier to manipulate with one hand while using the other to hold parts together. Those wanting a lanyard can tack a nut or washer as desired.

Yes, I often grab a C clamp when faced with removing a bolt with a rounded off head/nut or a round or pan head screw with ruined slots, or when I need to firmly grip smooth round stock to prevent it from spinning.
When you need to grip and twist/pull a rusted axle shaft out of some garden tool or old machinery, maybe even bang it out in reverse like a slide hammer, nothing beats a C clamp.
Also, when you're out in the field and break or lose a socket wrench handle or similar tool holder and need to make do or trek 50 miles to the nearest replacement, there's nothing better than grabbing that socket adapter or broken saw or knife blade or screwdriver tip with a C clamp.
Maybe you just need an extra set of pliers...fuck that multipurpose tool that takes up little space and IS adjustable pliers with a locking mechanism you don't have to use; grab a C CLAMP!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517902
> will weaken the bone
Bone is mostly collagen and calcium phosphate. You have to remove the collagen (which makes it flexible) because it’s a protein and will rot/decay/attract pests if you don’t.

If you cook it for long enough the bone pretty much falls off anyway and a shoe polishing brush or pressurised water stream (like a garden hose nozzle, no need for a pressure washer) will remove 99%.

Then you bleach it to remove organic remains, mold spores, prions and other disease spreading stuff that survived the boiling

>>2517902
I take my heads and dig a little circular trench to semi-bury the rim of an inverted metal mesh wastebasket. The head goes under there, with some heavy weights on top. After time the insects clean it pretty well, but not perfectly. Then I plonk the head into a 5 gallon bucket of water to let what's left putrefy. Change water maybe once a week, pick off the big pieces, do a rinse in-between bucket changes. Needle nose pliers help if you have some tough, slippery skin or ligaments. I never do boiling water or bleach. I like the natural bone colors. Other useful tools: scrub brushes, toothbrushes, nitrile gloves, goggles (meaty backspash). It's a labor of love to clean a good animal skull.

You don't want to boil because it weakens the bones. You cannot get good specimens doing that. You can buy some beetles and a tank or you could set the head outside on a balcony or something inside a mesh cage and let maggots eat some. For the water bucket putrefaction step you also want to set the bucket outside on a balcony or something. This really stinks. The whole process really smells. Don't do this inside your house or in an apartment. Wait for warmer weather. You will have trouble getting the death smell out of your home. Trying to think of how to change the water buckets without defiling your apartment. You may very well get the cops called on you or lose your lease for this. This is an outdoor activity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you live in the city, you're going to have problems.

The best way would be to use a combination of what people above have mentioned. Find somewhere where you can leave it for a few weeks and let nature take its course. Obviously it needs to be secured to stop larger predators taking it. After most of the flesh etc. is gone, you want to soak it in a bucket of water for a while to get into all the nooks and crannies. Adding a small amount of dish soap will help things along. Take it out and give it a good scrub and change the water every week or so. At this stage the teeth may potentially come loose so make sure you don't loose any. The dish soap is essential for degreasing the bones. To get a nice white finish, soak them in a 1:3 mixture of hydrogen peroxide to water.

Under no circumstances boil them as this will only trap the fat inside the bone and make them rot and smell. It also undermines the structural integrity of the bone. Also never use bleach as this will also weaken the bone structure.

Finally join a Facebook group for bone collectors or taxidermists. There are lot's of great communities that are happy help and will teach you a thing or two.

>>2519642
I advise against leaving skulls out in nature that long. First, despite your best security, a larger animal may figure out a way to move it. Second, weathering patterns are not going to be uniform. A long, long time ago when I was first collecting animal skulls, I left a red fox skeleton in a cage in the woods for over a year. The part of the skull facing up got sun bleached with an awful pitted texture. The part facing down got stained green from mold. You really only want it to be outside for as long as it takes for insects to clean most of the flesh, then you want to move it to the water buckets. Ideally, we can all have space for indoor beetle tanks, but we don't. You've gotta check on them every few weeks.

>>2505570
>You have...the ability to genuinely deep dive into anything and become a master at it.

What you don't acknowledge is that most people working in any trade or field aren't anywhere near being "masters" and don't need to be to do competent work. Often the people in top positions have very narrow and limited skill sets, and the more technical the work is the more likely they are to have extremely specialized capabilities.
In fields that require a broad range of skills and knowledge to be competent there are often concessions made in applying training resources based on the chance of encountering certain problems, so that it's often possible to literally have more education from a week perusing the internet than a licensed doctor or lawyer gets about certain rare situations that were barely mentioned on one or two pages in his school textbooks 15 years ago.
Building contractors in particular often know little more than how to pass a test and write contracts, which is all that most GC license schools focus on.
The ones who can actually speak authoritatively about actual construction gained that knowledge from working at all the different jobs involved, not shunning them.
Strong work teams that are adaptable and deal with fast paced critical situations make a point of having all the team members work at the various positions involved just to understand what is involved and so they can sub for each other in emergencies enough that they operation can at least limp along instead of being dead in the water..
That kind of thing is common in everything from retail stores to fabrication shops to boat crews to the military.

Also there's no guarantee that whatever you take a "deep dive" into will be around when you are even halfway to mastering it, and to stay employed you may need to take a hard turn from something like switchboard operator or typesetter or VCR repair tech into a new paradigm that renders much of your mastery and esoteric knowledge useless.

posts.com:
You don't necessarily need composite if you get pvc with foam insulation in the frame channels. Things like low e glazing help (some people think they're a scam, I haven't made up my mind yet). Argon gas is also pretty standard these days but that dissipates.

Dual pane glass should be fine. Biggest thing is making sure it's installed right and knowing that if you do go with a purely vinyl window there will be sag down the line with operable windows.
As for the patio door a slider will always be less efficienct than French doors, but French doors are typically more expensive. If you go with French doors pay the extra for fiberglass as they are typically better insulated than steel, and steel dent/rusts/demlainates much easier.

You won't get anything quickly unless your shit is all whatever is standard sizes in bongland, and that's only for the door. There are no "standard" window sizes but you might get lucky and have your RO be close to sizes that manufacturers run in bulk.

Quickest fix is plastic wrap and blankets over the windows.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My girlfriend loses her glasses about three times a year. I find them all over the house and in the car. I found them in the trunk once. Also in the top rack of the dishwasher once. Meanwhile I have never lost a pair and I have been wearing them since I was a kid. I have places I put them down; my nightstand, my desk, and the counter in the bathroom for when I am showers. I don't put them anywhere that is not those places. Do the same thing with your tools.

Have designated work areas and storage areas. Similar things should be in the same place. Don't have half your sockets in one toolbox and half in the other, etc. When you are done with a job (or it is on hold) you clean up the area and put shit back where it goes *even if you still need the tools for that job*. When work stops the tools get put away every time. Everything should have its place. That place should be the first place you look for a thing. If you find yourself looking somewhere else first, *move the thing to that place*.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Those are called expanding inner diameter laps and they're for precision grinding the insides of holes. You can use them by hand, with a drill, or really in any machine that rotates. The spiral cut allows them to expand a few thousands of an inch to achieve perfect sliding fits. Used carefully, they can achieve the best circularity and cylindricity of any tool, much better than a lathe for example. Very useful to have if you're making any kind of precision device out of metal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Use them with lapping compound to ream things out slightly and get a perfect fit.

On a side note, if you have a large bolt and nut that you don't have a tap for, (for example 1-1/2 diameter coarse thread) and you want a nice smooth hand spin fit for a project, you can put some valve lapping compound on the threads of the bolt and nut and run it up and down a bunch with a wrench making sure to keep the lapping compound spread around and it will make a nice fitting nut.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2515996
Better than a lathe??

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2516041
Yup. You can remove millionths of an inch. And the circularity improves because of how the lapping process averages out the surface, so you aren't dependent on the precision of your lathe's bearings or ways. The lapping process generates precision from scratch, much like how the 3 plate method creates a precision flat surface. Here's a good video on the cylindrical lapping process
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H2SeLcbcYkE

>>2515737
Gray water diversion and reuse is a thing, but there's issues that have to be addressed and more productive things to do with it than flushing toilets.
Biggest single issue is that *shocker* used bathwater isn't clean and gets nasty when stored untreated, same with washing machine discharge, both are full of skin particles and oils and dirt and bacteria that stink to high heaven when allowed to collect and stagnate.
Even if you designed a system that used gravity to avoid the extra costs of tanks, pumps and related plumbing and electrical connections you'd still have a toilet tank and bowl full of greasy putrid water that will reek.
Easy way to test this is just plug your tub when bathing/ showering and use a bucket to scoop that gray water out and flush your toilet, and see how it goes.
Picrel can theoretically save some water but in practice it's more about saving space and encouraging handwashing.
>>2515767
Gray water and other waste water from multiple individuals that is concentrated to a single discharge and at best is full of soap and other cleaning chemical residue isn't a natural part of any ecosystem; theres various ways of dealing with it safely and efficiently that may or may not work better than what exists in any particular circumstance but it's dumb to pretend that acknowledging that wastewater needs special handling is some kind of "delusion".
Also, solid waste *is* separated, recovered and re-used and liquid components recycled using minimal chemical treatment all the time.
If you are dead set against "chemicals", feel free to collect and use your water straight from the unsullied ecosystem where animals piss and shit in the water and vall kinds of deadly pathogens thrive.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2517078
So long as the new parts are replacing those which are designed to ve replaced (ball/acme screws, bearings, etc) or something beyond repair, so long as the replacement is made of the same material and look/function identically, I don't really see the issue. I'd much rather see someone breathe new life into a 60 year old vise/saw/whatever than to let it rot away on the shelf and buy a plastic one from Walmart that'll end up in a landfill after 6 months.

Preservation of the past is not best achieved through meticulously keeping those the artifacts of the past in a static, unchanging state. History isn't something relegated to the distant past. History is happening as you read this, and you are part of it. The way I see it, there's infinitely more value in a tool passed down 3 generations that's been entirely replaced by new parts than there is in one that remained completely unchanged (and unused) for all that time.

Obviously, there are limits to this. If nothing is captured statically, then how will future generations know what the past looked like? Two answers: for one, there are things that need to be kept static. Important documents and art, for example. Those things belong in museums (on display). Your grandpa's jigsaw from the late 60s is not one of those things. If you choose not to maintain it and use it, through whatever means necessary, it will be forgotten. It becomes waste. Additionally, if you keep using artifacts of the past in the present, there's never much question as to what the past looked like, since one can look down at the tool in their hand and see the answer for themselves.

A tip: if you're casting a slab, use larger pipes that require less pressure from your pump. Those pumps are ridiculously expensive for what they are.

i want to add to this that that you're able to transfer the same amount of heat at a lower temperature than with a regular radiator because the surface area is a lot higher.

TIG and MIG have the same amount of cleanup (there WILL be grinding no matter what process you choose), MIG just does the work 50x faster with 1/10th of the effort, and the added speed means you can put less heat into the panel which creates less warpage. Not to mention how much more prep work you need for TIG makes the prepwork twice as much work.

The people who genuinely clamor on about this are guys who get paid by the hour, or have never done bodywork in their life before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2514868
Practice on scrap first and put in at least an hour.

Before melting metal study modern options like Lord, 3M and other crash tested structural adhesives. They don't warp metal or risk hot spatter in places you can't put it out.

I've MIG, TIG and (love 'em) several "aircraft" style OA torches all of which work but adhesives can solve many problems with no heat distortion, and less corrosion risk if you live where that matters because you're not burning off inner paint or undercoat with heat.

https://www.lord.com/products-and-solutions/brands/fusor-repair-adhesives

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JEtHFNfx_rU

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=us-VVrhR4e0

Clecos etc are wonderful if you're doing serious work. If it's a shitbox blast it with FCAW , bash any protrusions below surface level then empty a dump truck full of Bondo onto the car/

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2514868
Prolly not. For automotive sheet metal work tig would be the best option. But careful bit of mig can achieve good results granted you go easy on the heat. Either way you'll have to grind flush.

Precautions? Make sure you probably strip and clean the metal so your HAZ does start burning paint and make sure you don't have any wires, tubes or insulation behind the panel you are working on. Preferably you should pop the spotwelds and fully remove the panel if you can.

Acetone and then denatured alcohol works wonders for cleaning post-strip. Just make sure you go back over with a dustless shop towel to make sure there isnt any residue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2511636
detergent and hot water after cleaning the majority of excess paint with mineral spirits also emulsifies with any remaining paint in the heel of the brush and prevent it from drying in there and stiffening up the bristles.
You can even work detergent like Dawn into the brush, squeeze out the excess and wrap it in some paper to block/set it, and just leave it to dry until you're ready to use it, and wash it out. When you do there will be even more oil based residue that comes out than if you just let it dry without the Dawn, and then you're ready to paint with WB or can use acetone to dry it for solvent based paint (or just let it air dry).

Also FYI it's an old painter trick to prep brand new brushes by soaking them in thinned material to saturate the hairs inside the ferrule and glue them together to prevent shedding. Then you clean them so the exposed bristles are clean and don't have to be picking hairs out of your paint for a month.

"French polishing is a wood finishing technique that results in a very high gloss surface, with a deep colour and chatoyancy. French polishing consists of applying many thin coats of shellac dissolved in denatured alcohol using a rubbing pad lubricated with one of a variety of oils. The rubbing pad is made of absorbent cotton or wool cloth wadding inside of a piece of fabric (usually soft cotton cloth)...

In the Victorian era, French polishing was commonly used on mahogany and other expensive timbers. It was considered the best finish for fine furniture and string instruments such as pianos and guitars. The process was very labour-intensive, and many manufacturers abandoned the technique around 1930, preferring the cheaper and quicker techniques of spray finishing nitrocellulose lacquer and abrasive buffing."

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2515908
the underlying primer coats were not sufficiently dry/cured to paint over.
Its worse in the corners because those areas are where the material goes on thickest and where air flow is most restricted and the moisture accumulates.
That means the primer there dries slower and the top coat stays wetter longer as well...when the primer layer is below a certain cure level that coat on top can essentially re-wet it and the combined weight of all those thick layers slides right off.

Alright, fucking fine, you're polite enough, I can appreciate that.
Air Conditioners:
There are many kinds; depending on your living arrangements, you can go with a window A/C unit, or a portable A/C unit.

Since you've got a room, it most likely depends on what access to the outdoors air you have - if you have a conventional sliding window, a window unit would be perfect.
Cheap, reliable, and easy to install.

If you have a sliding DOOR, or a fucked-up push out window (I have one), consider getting a unit on rolling casters.
Those have "adapters" to fit a seal around nearly any object, and the movability means you can take it with you if you ever move.
Less efficient than a window unit. Slightly more expensive.

Since you live in Australia, low humidity desert means you may be able to get away with a swamp cooler, memes aside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cont.
Installing an air conditioner is simple enough - most come with very basic installation instructions - it shouldn't take more than a day of work.

If you are female or a male on the underfed end, you may want help installing it, since those fuckers are a little heavy, especially if you're going to be lugging a bigger unit up stairs.
Last thing you want to happen is for it to fall out of the window while you're trying to bolt it in.

Basically, have a buddy when doing a job like that.
If you are a NEET, obtain assistance from your father; have some honour, and don't make your poor mother do the work.
Offer a buddy a pack of beer to help you install it.

No need to hire a professional for such a simple job.
However, if you're guaranteed to fuck it up, it can't hurt to pay a pro $100 to do it for you, especially if you want the least hassle possible.
Getting an A/C unit in the winter is the best time, but I think it's summer in Australia right now, and I don't know how economics work down there.

>>2518669
>you're polite enough
Yeah, I was gonna be snarky but this is true.
How much air conditioner to buy is the other question. The simple answer is: as much as you can afford. Bigger units are more efficient in general. And you'll run them less often to maintain temperature. (There is such a thing as too much, but it's rare and weird.)
As a VERY rough rule-of-thumb, you want about 30BTU per sq ft. E.g. a 16ftx16ft room is an 9000BTU AC. Or one notch bigger. Or one notch smaller.
>If you have a sliding DOOR, or a fucked-up push out window (I have one), consider getting a unit on rolling casters.
If you do go this route, be sure to get one which has two flexible tubes that go to the door/window. Why? Because the one tube model just exhausts the hot air out, which lowers the air pressure in the room, so every little window leak and vent and whatever you have outside is going to be pouring hot outside air into the room you're trying to cool. Two-tube systems circulate the outside air across the condensing coil and keep pressure normal.
